Invariant measures are fundamental for the study of dynamical systems. Replace the study of non-linear maps by the calculus of a linear eigenvector (fixed point of the push-forward operator).  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Invariant_measure…
------
Oldies but goldies: Hermann Minkowski, Geometrie der Zahlen, 1896. The Brunn-Minkowski inequality is one of the fundamental inequalities in convex geometry, which generalizes the isoperimetric inequality. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brunn%E2%80%93Minkowski_theorem… https://terrytao.wordpress.com/tag/brunn-minkowski-inequality/…
------
Image histograms, kernel non-parametric smoothing, & mean-shift are closely related. Here's how

Pick a reference pixel (center of a patch) & a set of other "helper" pixels (can be non-local) we can make an image-adaptive convolutional filter using histogram of pixel values

1/9
------
Iterating filters with small supports is equivalent to using a filter with an increasing size. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convolution…
------
Oldies but goldies: V.N. Vapnik, A.J. Chervonenkis, On the uniform convergence of relative frequencies of events to their probabilities. Defines the notion of VC dimension to ensure classification bounds of statistical learning methods, and introduces SVM. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/VC_dimension…
------
The pseudo-spectrum defines sets that encapsulate the eigenvalues. Their shape gives information about how ill-conditioned the spectrum is. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pseudospectrum…
------
Oldies but goodies: A.S. Lewis. Active sets, nonsmoothness, and sensitivity, 2002. Partial smoothness is the correct notion of "piecewise smooth functions" in optimization. Useful to study active set methods and relate optimization to differential geometry.
------
C'est officiel : la Maison Poincaré, le lieu où les #maths prennent vie, ouvre ses portes le samedi 30 septembre 2023 ! 

Et on en parle :
------
Quadratic discriminant analysis is a supervised classification method computing a maximum likelihood for Gaussian model. Linear discriminant analysis is the special case where the covariances are equal, and corresponds to the computation of Voronoi cells. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_discriminant_analysis…
------
Oldies but goldies: Holschneider, Kronland-Martinet, Morlet, Tchamitchian, A Real-Time Algorithm for Signal Analysis with the Help of the Wavelet Transform, 1990. The «à trou» algorithm computes convolution with large filters as a product of dilated filters.
------
This corresponds to the `dilation` parameter in 
@PyTorch
 It allows to compute translation-invariant CNN while still leveraging the ability to generate large receptive fields with relatively shallow networks (if you increase `dilation` while going deeper). https://pytorch.org/docs/stable/generated/torch.nn.Conv2d.html…
------
Floyd–Warshall algorithm computes all pairs shortest distances. Related to iterative powering of the adjacency matrix for the (min,+) algebra from Tropical geometry. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Floyd%E2%80%93Warshall_algorithm… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Min-plus_matrix_multiplication… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tropical_geometry…
------

A nice mathematical puzzle

If you take a 4-norm ball and cut it carefully, you will find a two-norm ball. 3D printed visual evidence below.
The puzzle: Why does this happen and how much more generally does it happen?

(This question was first posed to me by Pablo Parrilo)

Support vector machines (SVM) can be used to define curved decision boundaries  using the kernel trick. It implicitly makes use of an infinite dimensional feature lifting. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kernel_method…

Oldies but goldies: Bernhard Riemann, Ueber die Anzahl der Primzahlen unter einer gegebenen Grösse, 1859. Riemann hypothesis states that the only non-trivial zeros of the zeta function are on the line Re(s)=1/2. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Riemann_zeta_function…
------
The Johnson-Lindenstrauss lemma shows that one can project linearly m points in dimension log(m)/epsilon^2 with distortion epsilon. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johnson%E2%80%93Lindenstrauss_lemma…
------
Oldies but goldies: Daubechies, Defrise, De Mol, An iterative thresholding algorithm for linear inverse problems with a sparsity constraint, 2004. The ISTA algorithm to solve the LASSO is a special case of the Forward-Backward algorithm. http://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/gpeyre/numerical-tours/blob/master/python/ml_2_regression.ipynb…
------
Boosting methods compute a strong classifier as a weighted sum of weak classifiers. The optimization is performed by a greedy coordinate minimization. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boosting_(machine_learning)…

A math thread about some of the questions I've been thinking about lately. The goal is to answer some concrete questions about 2x2 matrices. Our starting point is the equation below--but it will take us on a journey through algebraic geometry, classical analysis, and more. 1/n
------
Oldies but goldies: J. Nash, The Imbedding Problem for Riemannian Manifolds, 1956, C^1 n-dimensional manifolds can be isometrically embedded in dimension 2n, defining « fractal » like surfaces. This contrasts with smooth manifolds (which requires > n(n+2)/2 dimensions).
------
The Euclidean Steiner tree looks for the shortest irrigation tree of nodes. At most p-2 extra (Steiner) points are needed, and they have a degree of 3 with an angle of 120°. Unlike the minimum spanning tree problem (without Steiner points), no efficient algorithm exists.
------
Back-propagation for feed-forward architectures is a special case of reverse-mode automatic differentiation. It computes the gradient of a loss function with a cost comparable to the computation of the loss function itself. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backpropagation…
------
Kaczmarz's algorithm corresponds to the iterative projection on the hyper-space defined by the columns. Here, the worst possible ordering of the constraints is displayed. Using random selection helps a lot. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kaczmarz_method…
------
Positive semi-definite matrices come in many flavors! https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Definite_symmetric_matrix…
------
Oldies but goldies: Carl Runge, Über empirische Funktionen und die Interpolation zwischen äquidistanten Ordinaten, 1901. Oscillations are introduced by polynomial interpolation at equi-spaced grid points. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Runge%27s_phenomenon…
------
Pruning the Voronoi diagram of a set of points is way to estimate the medial axis of a smooth curve. Used in many shape reconstruction methods. http://web.cs.ucdavis.edu/~amenta/pubs/crust.pdf… http://web.cse.ohio-state.edu/~dey.8/paper/medial.pdf…
------
A nice mathematical puzzle

If you take a 4-norm ball and cut it carefully, you will find a two-norm ball. 3D printed visual evidence below.
The puzzle: Why does this happen and how much more generally does it happen?

(This question was first posed to me by Pablo Parrilo)

To force myself to learn more about Wasserstein gradient flow (for OPT & ML), I made beginner-friendly lecture slides for a mini-course. I took a practical optimization (and simple ODE) perspective of viewing GF, via the variational principle. Slides here: https://jj-zhu.github.io/file/IWIAS-mini-course-opt-gf-aug-2023-nopause.pdf…
------
Oldies but goldies: B. Delaunay, Sur la sphère vide, 1934. Introduces the concept of Delaunay triangulation, which is the dual of the Voronoi diagram. The most fundamental tool of computational geometry. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delaunay_triangulation… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voronoi_diagram… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computational_geometry…
------
Support vector machines (SVM) can be used to define curved decision boundaries  using the kernel trick. It implicitly makes use of an infinite dimensional feature lifting. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kernel_method…
------
Oldies but goldies: Bernhard Riemann, Ueber die Anzahl der Primzahlen unter einer gegebenen Grösse, 1859. Riemann hypothesis states that the only non-trivial zeros of the zeta function are on the line Re(s)=1/2. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Riemann_zeta_function…
------
The Johnson-Lindenstrauss lemma shows that one can project linearly m points in dimension log(m)/epsilon^2 with distortion epsilon. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johnson%E2%80%93Lindenstrauss_lemma…
------
Oldies but goldies: Daubechies, Defrise, De Mol, An iterative thresholding algorithm for linear inverse problems with a sparsity constraint, 2004. The ISTA algorithm to solve the LASSO is a special case of the Forward-Backward algorithm. http://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/gpeyre/numerical-tours/blob/master/python/ml_2_regression.ipynb…
------
Boosting methods compute a strong classifier as a weighted sum of weak classifiers. The optimization is performed by a greedy coordinate minimization. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boosting_(machine_learning)…

------
The optimality conditions for this duality directly lead to the "DC-programming" algorithm https://ocw.mit.edu/courses/15-097-prediction-machine-learning-and-statistics-spring-2012/06d402cb88ff2cdb8e69b66a5c864b92_MIT15_097S12_proj5.pdf… This method has been re-introduced in ML  under the name "Convex-Concave Procedure" https://proceedings.neurips.cc/paper_files/paper/2001/file/a012869311d64a44b5a0d567cd20de04-Paper.pdf…
------

------
Numerical inverse kinematics solves an ill-posed inverse problem (non-unique solution) by gradient descent, thereby leveraging an "implicit bias" (favoring minimal displacements). It is at the heart of robotics and CG animation. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inverse_kinematics…
------
Progressive 3D slices of the 4-dimensional hypertorus. Notice the discrete critical points as the slice changes topology from a sphere, to a torus, then a genus-2 surface, with the equatorial slice being two separate tori.
------
Simplicial complexes are combinatorial objects generalizing triangulations. They are central to (computational) homology and topological data analysis. Two examples for embedded points are alpha and Chech complexes. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simplicial_complex…

The Legendre-Fenchel transform extends the Legendre transform to arbitrary dimensions. |x|^2/2 is the only fixed point of the transform. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Legendre_transformation…
------
The Shrödinger problem defines a dynamic interpolation between two distributions using Brownian bridges. The 0 temperature limit is Optimal Transport. https://hal.archives-ouvertes.fr/hal-00849930/document…

The case alpha=0 is special, since the backward flow is deterministic (noise is only added at initial time -- well here in my simulation there no noise at all!). I guess it does not work well for generative models (?). It is similar in spirit to normalizing flows.
------
Toland's duality for non-convex optimization (difference of convex functions) is surprisingly useful when the dual happens to be convex. A nice paper by Guillaume Carlier explores this concept. https://ceremade.dauphine.fr/~carlier/toland.pdf…
------
The proof being somehow even simpler than Fenchel-Rockafellar duality bc it is just an inf-inf exchange.
------
The optimality conditions for this duality directly lead to the "DC-programming" algorithm https://ocw.mit.edu/courses/15-097-prediction-machine-learning-and-statistics-spring-2012/06d402cb88ff2cdb8e69b66a5c864b92_MIT15_097S12_proj5.pdf… This method has been re-introduced in ML  under the name "Convex-Concave Procedure" https://proceedings.neurips.cc/paper_files/paper/2001/file/a012869311d64a44b5a0d567cd20de04-Paper.pdf…
------
Difference of convex (DC) programming are non-convex problem enjoying a nice duality theory and thus a simple optimization algorithm. http://lita.univ-lorraine.fr/~lethi/index.php/dca.html… https://ceremade.dauphine.fr/~carlier/toland.pdf…
------
An unusual blog post today: I try to explain why complex differentiation is so different from the real case, how to unify them using Wirtinger derivatives, and how this can be useful in practice, even if you don't use complex numbers!

https://lisyarus.github.io/blog/math/2023/08/03/complex-derivatives.html…
------
Anisotropic diffusion uses space-varying conductivity to slow down diffusion near edges, resulting in non-isotropic diffusion behavior. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anisotropic_diffusion…
------
Numerical inverse kinematics solves an ill-posed inverse problem (non-unique solution) by gradient descent, thereby leveraging an "implicit bias" (favoring minimal displacements). It is at the heart of robotics and CG animation. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inverse_kinematics…
------
Progressive 3D slices of the 4-dimensional hypertorus. Notice the discrete critical points as the slice changes topology from a sphere, to a torus, then a genus-2 surface, with the equatorial slice being two separate tori.
------
Simplicial complexes are combinatorial objects generalizing triangulations. They are central to (computational) homology and topological data analysis. Two examples for embedded points are alpha and Chech complexes. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simplicial_complex…
------
This can be heuristically derived by rewriting the original backward-in-time heat equation (which is unstable) by changing the sign of the Laplacian, at the expense of introducing the log density in the divergence.
------
The last ingredient is a pre-processing estimation of the score. This vector field is an optimal denoiser in the least squares sense, i.e., solution of an optimization problem. This score can be estimated as a neural network phi from noisy samples (X_t)_t using SGD.

------
The Fisher-Rao distance is the geodesic distance associated with smooth divergences (e.g., Kulback-Leibler). Without constraint, it is the Hellinger distance. On the manifold of Gaussians, it is a negatively curved space. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fisher_information_metric…
------
Möbius transforms are the bijective conformal maps from the Riemann sphere (complex numbers with a point at infinity) to itself. They are rational functions, form a group under composition, and have, in general, two fixed points (in black). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/M%C3%B6bius_transformation…

"Winding Numbers on Discrete Surfaces,"

with 
@nicolefeng_
 and 
@MarkGillespie64
.

In essence, we address the question: given a jumble of curves on a surface (possibly noisy & broken), which points are "inside" vs. "outside"? [1/n]
------
I have an interesting result for SGD (Stochastic gradient descent) with adaptive step sizes. I don't know if it's new or not, do. you? It's a convergence proof for stochastic, Lipschitz and convex losses, when using a modification of the Stochastic Polyak Stepsize, or SPS. 1/x
------
Displacement Interpolation, introduced by R McCann, is the optimal transport geodesic between 2 point clouds, more generally btw measures. Interpreting the space of measures as a manifold has countless implications and applications in physics, chemistry, signal processing, ML...
------
Can Heavy-ball accelerate beyond quadratics
In http://arxiv.org/pdf/2307.11291, with the fabulous Baptiste Goujaud & 
@TaylorAdrien
, we show that while it's one of the most prevalent 1st-order optimization methods, HB fails to accelerate on smooth and strongly-convex functions!

Space-invariant PDEs can be solved in closed form (without time integration) using the Fourier transform. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partial_differential_equation…
------
Weiszfeld's algorithm is an iterative least square method to compute medians (p=1) and, in general, sums of distance to some power p. Using p<2 makes the solution robust to outliers.
------
I think it is an open problem to prove convergence of the method to the solution outside a set of zero measure of "bad" initializations...
------
Triangulated graphs are maximal planar graphs, i.e., for which one cannot add an extra edge (without breaking planarity). The set of triangulated graphs is itself a connected graph when one navigates using "edge flips." https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flip_graph https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flip_graph

The trick to obtain ellipses in place of circles is to group positive and negative coefficients in pairs. This is actually quite neat.

In essence, we address the question: given a jumble of curves on a surface (possibly noisy & broken), which points are "inside" vs. "outside"? [1/n]

I have an interesting result for SGD (Stochastic gradient descent) with adaptive step sizes. I don't know if it's new or not, do. you? It's a convergence proof for stochastic, Lipschitz and convex losses, when using a modification of the Stochastic Polyak Stepsize, or SPS. 1/x
------
Displacement Interpolation, introduced by R McCann, is the optimal transport geodesic between 2 point clouds, more generally btw measures. Interpreting the space of measures as a manifold has countless implications and applications in physics, chemistry, signal processing, ML...
------
Can Heavy-ball accelerate beyond quadratics
In http://arxiv.org/pdf/2307.11291, with the fabulous Baptiste Goujaud & 
@TaylorAdrien
, we show that while it's one of the most prevalent 1st-order optimization methods, HB fails to accelerate on smooth and strongly-convex functions!

What Is the Pseudoinverse of a Matrix? https://nhigham.com/2023/07/25/what-is-the-pseudoinverse-of-a-matrix/…
------
The spherical Laplacian defines a set of orthogonal eigenspaces spanned by spherical harmonics. Display here is a random evolution in each space. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spherical_harmonics…
------
Space-invariant PDEs can be solved in closed form (without time integration) using the Fourier transform. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partial_differential_equation…
------
Weiszfeld's algorithm is an iterative least square method to compute medians (p=1) and, in general, sums of distance to some power p. Using p<2 makes the solution robust to outliers.
------
I think it is an open problem to prove convergence of the method to the solution outside a set of zero measure of "bad" initializations...
------
Triangulated graphs are maximal planar graphs, i.e., for which one cannot add an extra edge (without breaking planarity). The set of triangulated graphs is itself a connected graph when one navigates using "edge flips." https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flip_graph https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flip_graph
------
New blog post: perspectives on diffusion, or how diffusion models are autoencoders, deep latent variable models, score function predictors, reverse SDE solvers, flow-based models, RNNs, and autoregressive models, all at once!
------
Woodbury formula allows one to compute in two different ways the solution of Ridge regression. It allows one to even use infinite-dimensional feature spaces (p=inf) via kernelization. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Woodbury_matrix_identity… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tikhonov_regularization…
------
Total variation denoising can be solved by doing a projected gradient descent on the dual problem. The same idea applies to SVM with ridge regularization. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Total_variation_denoising…
------
The max of n independent Gaussians concentrates around sqrt(2log(n)). The max central limit theorem allows to quantify this. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fisher%E2%80%93Tippett%E2%80%93Gnedenko_theorem…
------
The hypercube (tesseract in dimension 4) is the d-dimensional cube. It can be visualized by projection on a rotating 3-D space. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tesseract https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypercube
------
Differentiable max & argmax operators are defined through concave maximization on the simplex. Soft and sparse max are particular cases. https://arxiv.org/abs/1602.02068 https://arxiv.org/abs/1705.07704 https://arxiv.org/abs/1802.03676 https://arxiv.org/abs/1802.04223
------
Curve approximation using Fourier series corresponds to drawing the curve using entangled ellipses. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fourier_series…
------
The trick to obtain ellipses in place of circles is to group positive and negative coefficients in pairs. This is actually quite neat.
------

I've proven the strangest result of my career..
The classic idea that gradient descent's rate is best with constant stepsizes 1/L is wrong. The idea that we need stepsizes in (0,2/L) for convergence is wrong.
Periodic long steps are better, provably.
https://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06324
------

------

------
Approximation vs quantization: two ways to compress. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantization… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Function_approximation…
------
Hopfield networks are recurrent networks minimizing an Ising-type energy parameterized by its weights. Learning weights means encoding patterns of +1/-1 as local minimizers. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hopfield_network…
------

New preprint “Abide by the Law and Follow the Flow: Conservation Laws for Gradient Flows” w. 
@SibylleMarcotte
 and 
@RemiGribonval
, we define and study “conservation laws” for the optimization of over-parameterized models. https://arxiv.org/abs/2307.00144
------
A consequence of our results is to show that conservation laws reported in the literature are maximal for 2-layer ReLU and linear NN: there is no other independent preserved quantity. For deeper NN, our SageMath toolbox also supports this claim for a wide range of architectures
------
Special thanks to 
@PierreAblin
 for a careful proofreading and useful suggestions! Credits will be added in the v2 of the preprint...

New preprint “Abide by the Law and Follow the Flow: Conservation Laws for Gradient Flows” w. 
@SibylleMarcotte
 and 
@RemiGribonval
, we define and study “conservation laws” for the optimization of over-parameterized models. https://arxiv.org/abs/2307.00144
------
A consequence of our results is to show that conservation laws reported in the literature are maximal for 2-layer ReLU and linear NN: there is no other independent preserved quantity. For deeper NN, our SageMath toolbox also supports this claim for a wide range of architectures
------
Special thanks to 
@PierreAblin
 for a careful proofreading and useful suggestions! Credits will be added in the v2 of the preprint...
------
For 2-layer ReLU and linear networks, we compute explicitly the traces of the Lie algebras. For the general case, we implement in SageMath an algorithm to compute these traces.
------
Shapiro's inequality: for small integers, cyclic sums of quotients is always larger than n/2. For large n, it only gets strictly smaller by 1%. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shapiro_inequality…
------
skglm v0.3 is out!

Interested in survival analysis?  We now have a blazing fast Cox Estimator 

100% compatible with scikit-learn, already applied to previously out of reach real data
https://contrib.scikit-learn.org/skglm/auto_examples/plot_survival_analysis.html#sphx-glr-auto-examples-plot-survival-analysis-py…

kudos to 
@badr_moufad
 
@el_PA_B
!

New paper out : a simple way to have optimal transport with sparse displacements

"Monge, Bregman and Occam: Interpretable Optimal Transport in High-Dimensions with Feature-Sparse Maps"

https://arxiv.org/abs/2302.04065

w. 
@CuturiMarco
 and Michal Klein

A small thread
------
Understanding global convergence of Newton method is hard ...  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newton_fractal…
------
The Wasserstein and Hellinger distances between Gaussians can be computed in closed form. http://djalil.chafai.net/blog/2020/01/22/about-the-hellinger-distance/…
------
Lloyd algorithm can be applied on a surface using the geodesic Voronoi diagram. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lloyd%27s_algorithm… http://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/gpeyre/numerical-tours/blob/master/matlab/fastmarching_4_mesh.ipynb…
------
Hölder inequality generalizes Cauchy-Schwarz to arbitrary exponents. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H%C3%B6lder%27s_inequality…
------
Approximation vs quantization: two ways to compress. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantization… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Function_approximation…
------
Hopfield networks are recurrent networks minimizing an Ising-type energy parameterized by its weights. Learning weights means encoding patterns of +1/-1 as local minimizers. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hopfield_network…
------
Our joint work with 
@YohannDCstr
 and Vincent Duval is finally out: https://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03709

"Exact recovery of the support of piecewise constant images via total variation regularization"
------
Heat, Wave and Schrodinger equations are fundamental linear partial differential equations of physics. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heat_equation… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wave_equation… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schr%C3%B6dinger_equation…
------
Minkowski inequality states that the l^p norm is a norm. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minkowski_inequality…
------
Haar transform: only + and - yet surprisingly powerful. The first example of wavelet transform. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haar_wavelet…
------
An alternate way (and imho better) to define this transform is using two lifting steps, as introduced by 
@wimsweldens
 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lifting_scheme…
------
Pullback of functions and pushforward of measures are dual one with each other. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pullback https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pushforward_measure…
------
The hairy ball theorem states that in odd dimension d, vector fields on the tangent plane of a (d-1)-sphere necessarily contain a singular point (where it vanishes). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hairy_ball_theorem…
------
Representation theory defines a Fourier transform on groups. Finite commutative groups correspond to the classical discrete Fourier transform. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Representation_theory_of_finite_groups… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fourier_transform_on_finite_groups…
------
New preprint “Abide by the Law and Follow the Flow: Conservation Laws for Gradient Flows” w. 
@SibylleMarcotte
 and 
@RemiGribonval
, we define and study “conservation laws” for the optimization of over-parameterized models. https://arxiv.org/abs/2307.00144
------
A consequence of our results is to show that conservation laws reported in the literature are maximal for 2-layer ReLU and linear NN: there is no other independent preserved quantity. For deeper NN, our SageMath toolbox also supports this claim for a wide range of architectures
------
Special thanks to 
@PierreAblin
 for a careful proofreading and useful suggestions! Credits will be added in the v2 of the preprint...
------
For 2-layer ReLU and linear networks, we compute explicitly the traces of the Lie algebras. For the general case, we implement in SageMath an algorithm to compute these traces.
------
Shapiro's inequality: for small integers, cyclic sums of quotients is always larger than n/2. For large n, it only gets strictly smaller by 1%. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shapiro_inequality…
------

Elastic net (Zou , Hastie, 2005) interpolates between the Lasso (l1 regularization) and Ridge regression (l2 regularization). The regularization path of Lasso is polygonal. The one of elastic net is piecewise smooth. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elastic_net_regularization… http://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/gpeyre/numerical-tours/blob/master/python/ml_2_regression.ipynb…

The mean curvature motion is the most fundamental curve evolution. It is the equivalent for curves of the heat equation. It is independent of parameterisation (intrinsic) and minimizes the length of the curve (shortening flow). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curve-shortening_flow…
------
A Riemannian manifold is locally an Euclidean space. An embedded surface (e.g. the Earth) is an example. It defines a Riemannian tensors field (first fundamental form) in parametric space which encode length deformations. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Riemannian_manifold… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parametric_surface#First_fundamental_form…
------
The geodesic distance extends a local metric into a global one. Geodesic curves define networks of curves that are similar to spanning trees on a graph. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geodesic https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Riemannian_manifold…
------
Elastic net (Zou , Hastie, 2005) interpolates between the Lasso (l1 regularization) and Ridge regression (l2 regularization). The regularization path of Lasso is polygonal. The one of elastic net is piecewise smooth. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elastic_net_regularization… http://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/gpeyre/numerical-tours/blob/master/python/ml_2_regression.ipynb…
------
Error checking code with an additional parity bit defines a simplex in the binary cube. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parity_bit
------
We are opening a tenure track position in the field of Artificial Intelligence for biology and medicine.

You can find the details here: 
https://cbio.mines-paristech.fr/pdf-files/tenure-track-position-cr-artificial-intelligence-for-biology-and-medicine…
------
Pinsker inequality is one of the most fundamental inequality in information theory. Upper bounds the total variation (i.e. l^1 norm) by the square root of the relative entropy (i.e. the Kullback-Leibler divergence). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pinsker%27s_inequality…
------
The Levenberg-Marquardt is a standard method for non-linear least-squares, combining the best of gradient descent and Newton methods by replacing the Hessian by the Jacobian term only. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Levenberg%E2%80%93Marquardt_algorithm…
------
 C'est parti pour le workshop optimisation et apprentissage machine organisé par les instituts 3IA de Toulouse et Paris, #ANITI et #PRAIRIE.

Pour en savoir + sur le programme de ces 2 journées : https://aniti.univ-toulouse.fr/2023/05/16/aniti-et-prairie-vous-invitent-a-un-workshop-optimisation/…
------
Non-circular gears generate non-regular motions from regular one. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-circular_gear…
------
Principal component analysis and non-negative matrix factorization are two particular of non-convex matrix factorization problem. They differ by the constraints on the atoms D and coefficients X. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Principal_component_analysis… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-negative_matrix_factorization…
------
Minimizing sum of p-powers of the distance generalizes the mean (p=2). For p=1, one obtains the median which is robust to outliers. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geometric_median…

Curse and blessing of non-smooth optimization: non-smooth parts (eg corners of sets) attract the solutions of optimization problems (e.g. projection on sets). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subderivative… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Variational_analysis…

The average distance to origin of a Brownian motion at time t grows like sqrt(t). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brownian_motion…

------
Continued fractions are in some sense optimal ways to approximate with rational numbers. Expansion of rational are finite. Expansion of quadratic numbers are periodic. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continued_fraction…
------
Fourier transforms comes with lots of flavors. Sampling and periodization are dual operations which interleave these transforms. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fourier_transform…
------
Reverse mode automatic-differentiation is based on a « backward » (adjoint) chain rule. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automatic_differentiation#Reverse_accumulation…

------
The mean curvature motion is the most fundamental curve evolution. It is the equivalent for curves of the heat equation. It is independent of parameterisation (intrinsic) and minimizes the length of the curve (shortening flow). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curve-shortening_flow…
------
A Riemannian manifold is locally an Euclidean space. An embedded surface (e.g. the Earth) is an example. It defines a Riemannian tensors field (first fundamental form) in parametric space which encode length deformations. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Riemannian_manifold… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parametric_surface#First_fundamental_form…
------
The integral curves of a vector field tangent to a manifold stays on the manifold. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integral_curve…
------
The primary visual cortex is organised as an oriented wavelet transform. Huber and Wiesel got the Nobel prize for this discovery. Mapping the orientation on the surface of the cortex creates singularities called pinwheells. https://sciencedirect.com/journal/journal-of-physiology-paris/vol/97/issue/2-3… https://youtube.com/watch?v=IOHayh06LJ4…

Approximation using  triangulations performs optimal compression of cartoon images. Finding the optimal triangulation is intractable, heuristics are used in practice. Wavelets are suboptimal, but still very much used because of linear time algorithms. https://arxiv.org/abs/1101.1555

------
The Reeb graph of a function on a manifold is the graph of level sets ordered by inclusion. For a 2D function (an image), it is the contour graph, and is actually a directed tree (polytree). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reeb_graph https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polytree
------
Schatten p-norms are the l^p norms of the singular values. Define algebra norm invariant by isometries. Generalizes the nuclear norm (p=1), Frobenius norm (p=2) and the operator norm (p=inf). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schatten_norm…
------
And it is a convex function!
------
A Brownian motion is approximated by a discrete random walk with Gaussian increments. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brownian_motion…
------
Discrete Cosine Transforms are eigenvectors of Laplacians with different boundary conditions. Wonderful paper by Strang. http://www-math.mit.edu/~gs/papers/dct.pdf…
------
The Fermat–Torricelli point minimizes the sum of the distance to the vertices of a triangle. If the angles are less than 120°, can be computed by forming three equilateral triangles, otherwise it is one of the vertices. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fermat_point…
------
Comparison of the Wasserstein, Hellinger, Kullback-Leibler and reverse KL on the space of Gaussian distributions. http://djalil.chafai.net/blog/2020/01/22/about-the-hellinger-distance/…

Fourier transforms comes with lots of flavors. Sampling and periodization are dual operations which interleave these transforms. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fourier_transform…

Eigenvalues of random matrices with iid entries converge to the Wigner circle law. This is universal (does not depend on the law of the entries), as proved by Tao and Vu in 2010. For Gaussian matrices, this defines a determinental point process. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Circular_law…

Schatten p-norms are the l^p norms of the singular values. Define algebra norm invariant by isometries. Generalizes the nuclear norm (p=1), Frobenius norm (p=2) and the operator norm (p=inf). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schatten_norm…
------
And it is a convex function!
------
A Brownian motion is approximated by a discrete random walk with Gaussian increments. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brownian_motion…
------
Discrete Cosine Transforms are eigenvectors of Laplacians with different boundary conditions. Wonderful paper by Strang. http://www-math.mit.edu/~gs/papers/dct.pdf…
------
The Fermat–Torricelli point minimizes the sum of the distance to the vertices of a triangle. If the angles are less than 120°, can be computed by forming three equilateral triangles, otherwise it is one of the vertices. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fermat_point…
------
Comparison of the Wasserstein, Hellinger, Kullback-Leibler and reverse KL on the space of Gaussian distributions. http://djalil.chafai.net/blog/2020/01/22/about-the-hellinger-distance/…
------
Zero crossing of the derivative of a blurred version (heat diffusion) of a function defines the so-called scale space representation. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scale_space…
------
Csiszar divergences compare the relative distributions of two histograms with 1. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F-divergence…
------
Eigenvalues of random matrices with iid entries converge to the Wigner circle law. This is universal (does not depend on the law of the entries), as proved by Tao and Vu in 2010. For Gaussian matrices, this defines a determinental point process. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Circular_law…
------
Filtered back-propagation is a formula for the invert of the Radon transform, which can be approximated by using a finite of Radon projections. The basic method to reconstruct images in scanner imaging. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tomographic_reconstruction…
------
A sub-group of Möbius transforms are those preserving the Poincaré upper-half (equivalently the disk). It corresponds to PSL(2) the 2x2 matrices with determinant 1. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/M%C3%B6bius_transformation#Subgroups_of_the_M%C3%B6bius_group…
------
Optimization can be carried over on manifolds using gradient descent, where the manifold gradient is the projection of an extrinsic gradient on the tangent plane. https://sites.uclouvain.be/absil/amsbook/
------
Unfortunately the expression for the Riemannian Hessian is less simple than for the gradient ... (basically bc you also have to differentiate the projector on the tangent plane, which makes curvature appear). https://sites.uclouvain.be/absil/2013-01/Weingarten_07PA_techrep.pdf…
------
Approximation using  triangulations performs optimal compression of cartoon images. Finding the optimal triangulation is intractable, heuristics are used in practice. Wavelets are suboptimal, but still very much used because of linear time algorithms. https://arxiv.org/abs/1101.1555
------
The distance field is the unique viscosity solution of the Eikonale equation. Pierre-Louis Lions got the Fields medal in 1994 in part for this concept. https://projecteuclid.org/euclid.jmsj/1230130200…  http://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/gpeyre/numerical-tours/blob/master/python/fastmarching_0_implementing.ipynb…
------
The subdifferential is the set of slopes bellow the graph of a convex function. It is a set-valued monotone map. Generalize the gradient to non-smooth functions. The most fundamental tool of non-smooth convex analysis. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subderivative…
------
A 1 hidden layer perceptron can approximate arbitrary continuous functions using a large enough number of neutrons (Cybenko's theorem). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universal_approximation_theorem… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multilayer_perceptron…

Summing the log of the nearest neighbors distances: a simple estimator for the entropy from samples. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Entropy_estimation…
------
Line integral convolution is an anisotropic filtering which averages values along streamlines. Can be used for vizualization of vector fields by diffusing noise. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Line_integral_convolution…
------
The heat equation can be applied on a surface and to a surface. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laplace%E2%80%93Beltrami_operator…
------
Penrose tiling are aperiodic tilings obtained using typically 2 isosceles triangles with two type of edge labelings (so 4 types of triangles). A way to generate the tiling is by applying iterative edge splitting using the golden ratio. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Penrose_tiling…
------
Code words defined using a Huffman tree generate codes with optimal average length. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Huffman_coding… https://youtube.com/watch?v=JsTptu56GM8&t=310s…
------
Lorenz attractor is the set of limit trajectories for a simplified mathematical model for atmospheric convection. It has a fractal geometry. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lorenz_system…
------
Radial basis functions performs interpolation and approximation by solving a linear system. In some cases (e.g. Gaussian and polyharmonic), corresponds to regression in a reproducing Hilbert space. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radial_basis_function…
------
(in 1D and for rotation invariant measures they are the same)
------
Self-organizing maps of Kohonen defines a map between a 2D space to the data, by minimizing a quantization error and a regularity penalty. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-organizing_map…
------
Behavior of dynamical system depends on the eigenvalues. In 2D it can be classified according to the trace and determinant. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stability_theory…  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_dynamical_system…
------
Taylor series expansion of sine. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taylor_series…
------
This radius can be computed using Cauchy–Hadamard theorem. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cauchy%E2%80%93Hadamard_theorem…
------
But a more geometric/natural way to see the problem is to look at the function over the complex plane, there is a singularity at i and -i. So although it looks nice over the real line, it is not nice over the imaginary line. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radius_of_convergence…
------
Störmer, Verlet and leapfrog are different names for the same method. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leapfrog_integration… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verlet_integration…
------
Tutte theorem defines a valid drawing of planar graphs by solving a linear system. A fundamental tool to compute surface parameterization.   https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tutte_embedding… http://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/gpeyre/numerical-tours/blob/master/python/meshdeform_1_parameterization.ipynb…
------
Varadhan formula shows that at first order, the heat kernel is equal to the geodesic kernel. They are exactly equal on Euclidean spaces. http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpa.3160200210/abstract…
------
Linear approximation selects the first coefficients of a decomposition in an orthogonal basis. Non-linear selects the best coefficients. Non-linear approximation in a Wavelet basis is efficient to handle non-smooth functions. http://people.math.sc.edu/devore/publications/NLACTA.pdf…
------
The Marchenko-Pastur law is the distribution limit of eigenvalues of covariance matrices when samples and size grow together. http://djalil.chafai.net/blog/2011/01/29/the-marchenko-pastur-…
------
The fractional Laplacian is a differential operator generalizing the Laplacian. They are the only rotation/translation/scale invariant linear operator. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fractional_Laplacian…
------
Summing the log of the nearest neighbors distances: a simple estimator for the entropy from samples. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Entropy_estimation…
------

------
Behavior of dynamical system depends on the eigenvalues. In 2D it can be classified according to the trace and determinant. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stability_theory…  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_dynamical_system…
------
The convex hull is the smallest enclosing convex set. It is also the intersection of all half-spaces containing the points, and the set of all possible convex combinations. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convex_hull…
------
The binomial law is a sum of Bernoulli 0/1 random variables. After rescaling, converge to a Gaussian for a large number of variables (a particular case of the central limit theorem).  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binomial_distribution…
------
The heat equation can be applied to diffuse probability densities (in particular, maintains positivity and unit mass). Its solution is obtained as the convolution of the initial condition with a Gaussian. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heat_equation…

Taylor series of exp(it) up to degree 15. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taylor_series…
------
Leapfrog/Verlet are symplectic integrators which approximately conserve hamiltonian, preserve periodic behaviors and are exactly reversible. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leapfrog_integration… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verlet_integration…
------
K-nearest neighbors is the baseline method for non-parametric classification. Computes an estimate of the relative density of the two classes.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/K-nearest_neighbors_algorithm…
------
Power iterations do not converge for matrices with multiple complex eigenvalues with same maximum modulus.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_iteration…
------
Tensor-driven anisotropic diffusion solves the heat equation on a manifold defined by a tensor field. At the heart of many methods for image restauration, texture enhancement and vizualization. The book of Joachim Weickert is a must read. https://mia.uni-saarland.de/weickert/Papers/book.pdf…

The damped harmonic oscillator (linear) vs simple gravity pendulum (non-linear). The two most celebrated second order dynamical systems. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harmonic_oscillator… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pendulum_(mathematics)#Simple_gravity_pendulum…
------
Lagrangian discretization of measures: quotient space. Eulerian discretization: convex polytope.
------
Thin plate spline is one of the most popular data interpolation methods. Its solution can be written in 2D using the r^2*log(r) radial basis function. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thin_plate_spline#cite_note-Duchon76-1…

------
Impact of the interpolation method on the level set of the resulting function. https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marching_cubes… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Level_set
------
Dual number is a convenient way to implement forward mode of automatic differentiation.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dual_number…
------
It can be understood as an algorithmic (stable) way to do finite difference to compute derivatives. It is advantageous when the number of input is small with respect to the number of outputs. Otherwise it is better to do reverse mode automatic differentiation (back propagation).

Thin plate spline is one of the most popular data interpolation methods. Its solution can be written in 2D using the r^2*log(r) radial basis function. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thin_plate_spline#cite_note-Duchon76-1…
------
Impact of the interpolation method on the level set of the resulting function. https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marching_cubes… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Level_set
------
Dual number is a convenient way to implement forward mode of automatic differentiation.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dual_number…
------
It can be understood as an algorithmic (stable) way to do finite difference to compute derivatives. It is advantageous when the number of input is small with respect to the number of outputs. Otherwise it is better to do reverse mode automatic differentiation (back propagation).
------
Poljak heavy ball and Nesterov methods speed up gradient descent by introducing momentum. Corresponding to second order ODEs. https://distill.pub/2017/momentum/
------
Daubechies wavelets is a parametric family of orthogonal Wavelets.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daubechies_wavelet…  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ingrid_Daubechies…
------
The mean-shift algorithm is a clustering method that progressively evolves points toward local maximum of a kernel density estimator. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mean_shift
------
The Helmholtz-Hodge decomposition split vectors fields in two orthogonal subspaces: incompressible and irrotational. In 2-D, corresponds to the sum of a gradient field and a rotated gradient field. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helmholtz_decomposition…
------
The logistic map can have complex patterns of adherence points depending on the value of its scale parameter r. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logistic_map…
------
Leapfrog/Verlet are symplectic integrators which approximately conserve hamiltonian, preserve periodic behaviors and are exactly reversible. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leapfrog_integration… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verlet_integration…
------
K-nearest neighbors is the baseline method for non-parametric classification. Computes an estimate of the relative density of the two classes.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/K-nearest_neighbors_algorithm…
------
Power iterations do not converge for matrices with multiple complex eigenvalues with same maximum modulus.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_iteration…
------
Tensor-driven anisotropic diffusion solves the heat equation on a manifold defined by a tensor field. At the heart of many methods for image restauration, texture enhancement and vizualization. The book of Joachim Weickert is a must read. https://mia.uni-saarland.de/weickert/Papers/book.pdf…
------
Stochastic gradient method: works also for infinite sums and expectation. Introduced by Herbert Robbins and Sutton Monro. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_approximation… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_gradient_descent…
------
The proximal operator is the implicit counterpart of the explicit gradient descent step. Fundamental to tackle non-smooth optimization problems. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proximal_operator…
------
Iterative projections: converge in theory for convex sets. Works great in practice for non-convex sets. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Projections_onto_convex_sets…
------

The logistic map can have complex patterns of adherence points depending on the value of its scale parameter r. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logistic_map…
------
The co-area formula relates the total variation to the perimeters of the level set. Can be extended to (possibly) discontinuous functions of bounded total variation. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coarea_formula…
------
The gradient flow of the Dirichlet energy is the heat equation, which blur edges. The total variation flow makes the image cartoon-like. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heat_equation… https://uv.es/mazon/trabajos/DIE.pdf… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Total_variation_denoising…
------
A Sobolev ball is an ellipsoid in infinite dimension aligned along the Fourier axes. A random Sobolev function has a Fourier transform with random phase. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sobolev_space…
------
Here the animation shows alpha progressively increasing and the image is drawn randomly in the Sobolev ball. alpha somehow corresponds to the smoothness (number of derivatives) of the image.
------
You can see this as denoising a pure noise image (as in diffusion model, but with a linear neural network).
------
John’s and Löwner’s ellipsoids are polar one from each others. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_ellipsoid…

The Legendre transform can be approximated in O(n*log(n)) using a Gaussian convolution. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Legendre_transformation…  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lower_convex_envelope…
------
Lloyd algorithm can be used to progressively diffuse points, defining a dynamical system over distributions. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lloyd%27s_algorithm…
------
Gauss-Luca theorem shows that the roots of the derivative of a polynomial belong to the convex hull of the roots of the polynomial. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gauss%E2%80%93Lucas_theorem…
------
One can map a surface to a sphere by minimizing a Dirichlet energy. https://numerical-tours.com/matlab/meshdeform_2_parameterization_sphere…
------
Interpolating linearly polynomials of a fixed degree defines an interpolation between their roots. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vieta%27s_formulas…
------
John’s and Löwner’s ellipsoids are polar one from each others. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_ellipsoid…
------
The kernel of a domain is the (convex) set of locations from which you can see all other locations in the domain. It is the intersections of all half-planes tangent to the shape. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star-shaped_polygon…
------
Only harmonic spring and gravity central forces produce periodic motions. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bertrand%27s_theorem…
------
Poljak heavy ball method speeds up gradient descent by introducing momentum. Corresponding to second order ODEs. https://distill.pub/2017/momentum/
------
Lotka–Volterra equations is a non-linear 2D ODE modeling prey/predator behaviors which exhibits periodic solutions.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lotka%E2%80%93Volterra_equations…
------
The harmonic oscillator is the canonical linear second order ODE. Parametrized by a single damping parameter. Solutions are (possibly complex) exponentials. Interpolates between periodic motion and exponential decay.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harmonic_oscillator…
------
This video demonstrates progressive decompression of a 3D mesh. http://cs.technion.ac.il/~gotsman/AmendedPubl/SpectralCompression/SpectralCompression.pdf…
------
The l1 norm provides an optimal balance between convexity and sparsity. It is used in various applications including the lasso and basis pursuit denoising, pioneered by David Donoho and Robert Tibshirani. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basis_pursuit_denoising…, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lasso_(statistics)…
------
Kriging (aka Wiener interpolation) is a method for kernel interpolation that accounts for uncertainty using Gaussian processes. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kriging
------
The Game of Life is a well-known 2D cellular automaton. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conway%27s_Game_of_Life…
------
The Delaunay triangulation in d dimensions can be obtained by computing the convex hull on a paraboloid lifting in d+1 dimensions. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delaunay_triangulation#d-dimensional_Delaunay…
------
Reasonable properties (convexity, differentiability, stratifiability, partial-smoothness ...) lift from vectors to matrices! https://people.orie.cornell.edu/aslewis/publications/03-mathematics.pdf…
------
Comparing probability distributions: Csiszár f-divergences measure « vertical » displacement of mass, whereas dual norm of smooth functions rather measure « horizontal » displacements. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F-divergence…
------
Marden theorem states that the roots of P'' are the focal point of the Steiner ellipse (largest enclosed ellipse in area) of the  triangle formed by the roots of P. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marden%27s_theorem…

------

------

Hyperbolic PDEs (e.g. wave) displace singularities. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heat_equation…  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wave_equation…  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parabolic_partial_differential_equation…  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyperbolic_partial_differential_equation…
------
Banach fixed point theorem ensures existence of a unique fixed point for contracting maps. The proof is constructive by iterating the map. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Banach_fixed-point_theorem…
------
The Wasserstein-1 distance (which is a norm!) between histograms on graphs is equivalent to a min-cost flow. Bold black indicates edges where mass is flowing. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minimum-cost_flow_problem…
------
Step size selection is important for gradient descent on ill-conditioned functions.
------
Bernstein polynomials can be used to approximate 1D functions but also 2D curves (corresponding to Bezier curves). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bernstein_polynomial…
------
The medial axis (aka the skeleton) generalizes the mediatrix between two points. Set of points where the distance function is not smooth. Set of points that have two equi-spaced closed points. For discrete points, delimitates the Voronoi diagrams.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medial_axis…
------
Polynomial maps exhibit bifurcations and chaotic behavior for some values of their coefficients. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logistic_map…
------
The Optimal Transport geometry of 1-D Gaussians is flat in the (mean,std) plane. In particular, the OT interpolation is a linear interpolation of mean and std.
------
Reproducing Kernel Hilbert spaces define norms on functions so that solutions of regularized fitting problems are linear sum of kernel functions. Defines non-parametric learning methods (complexity scales with input). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reproducing_kernel_Hilbert_space…
------
Reaction-diffusions are nonlinear PDEs which describe the formation of a surprisingly rich family of patterns. Introduced by Alan Turing in 1952. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reaction%E2%80%93diffusion_system…  http://dna.caltech.edu/courses/cs191/paperscs191/turing.pdf…
------
The Weierstrass function is continuous if a<1 but nowhere differentiable if ab>1. The Hausdorff dimension of its graph was conjectured by Mandelbrot in 1977 and proved by Shen in 2016. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weierstrass_function… 
https://arxiv.org/abs/1505.03986
------
Monotone operators (Minty, Browder) generalize monotone functions. (sub)-gradients of convex functions are (maximal) monotone. Skew-symmetric (gradients of min-max) operators are also monotone. These are the two extremal cases (Asplund). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monotonic_function…
------
The SVD decomposes the action of a matrix into rotations and scalings along the axes. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Singular_value_decomposition…
------
The QR decomposition can be computed in a numerically stable way using planar rotation matrices. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Givens_rotation…
------
Loyds algorithm defines a segmentation of the domain using Voronoi cells. The associated dual graph is a Delaunay triangulation. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lloyd%27s_algorithm…
------
The heat can be applied to diffuse probability density (in particular, maintains positivity and unit mass). It corresponds to the distribution of a Brownian motion at time t. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heat_equation…
------
« Greedy »  gradient descent using optimal step choice at each iteration produces orthogonal successive directions. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gradient_descent…
------
Csiszár divergences is a unifying way to define losses between arbitrary positive measures (discrete & densities). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F-divergence…  https://arxiv.org/abs/math/0209021…
------
The QR decomposition can be computed in a numerically stable way using reflection matrices. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Householder_transformation…

------
Non-uniform B-splines functions are smooth piecewise polynomial functions, which can be generalized to rational functions by weighting (NURBS). The backbone of computer aided geometric design and extensively used in computer graphics. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-uniform_rational_B-spline…
------
One can encode or approximate convex shapes as intersections of the semi-definite positive cone and affine spaces (linear matrix inequalities). This allows one to use interior point methods to solve optimization on these sets. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_matrix_inequality…
------
Total variation denoising (Leonid Rudin, Stanley Osher, Emad Fatemi, 92) was studied in theory among others by Vicent Caselles. He proved (with collaborators including Antonin Chambolle) that it does not create discontinuities but blurs corners. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Total_variation_denoising…

Positive 1D polynomials are sums of squares. Motzkin’s 2D polynomial is positive but is not a sum of squares. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Positive_polynomial… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sum-of-squares_optimization…
------
The Courant-Friedrichs-Lewy (CFL) condition relates time/space step sizes for the stability of finite difference methods. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Courant%E2%80%93Friedrichs%E2%80%93Lewy_condition…
------
L2 (ridge) vs L1 (lasso) are used for the regularization of regression problems. L1 induces a sparsity prior and correctly recovers isolated spikes even with correlated designs. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tikhonov_regularization… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lasso_(statistics)…
------
Geometry of Gaussians: Optimal Transport is flat (Euclidean) while Fisher-Rao is hyperbolic (Poincaré half-plane).
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fisher_information_metric…
------
Gradient flows on metric spaces: define descent methods on non-Euclidean domains without using a gradient. A key tool studied in details by Ambrosio, Gigli and Savare. http://springer.com/la/book/9783764387211…
------
Pinsker's inequality is a fundamental inequality of information theory. Bounds the total variation norm by the relative entropy (aka KL divergence). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pinsker%27s_inequality…
------
Training a multilayer perceptron with a single hidden layer corresponds to the evolution of a sparse probability measure (sum of Dirac masses) over the neuron's parameter domain (here it is 2D for the regression of a 1D function, slope+position of the ridge).
------
Iterative closest point is one of the basic algorithms for rigid shape registration. Leverages the closed form formula of least square rigid motion. Can be coupled with optimal transport (e.g. Hungarian algorithm).  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iterative_closest_point…
------
Adding an independent Gaussian variable is the same as doing a heat diffusion on the density. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convolution_of_probability_distributions…
------
Fixed points can be attractive or repulsive depending on the derivative of the map. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fixed_point_(mathematics)…
------
Harris’s method is the most frequently used corner detector, based on the eigenvalues of the structure tensor. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harris_Corner_Detector…
------
Schrodinger’s problem is an approximation (regularization using diffusion) of the Optimal Transport problem. https://arxiv.org/abs/1308.0215
------
The Travelling salesman problem is one of the most well known NP-hard problem. Concorde’s solver can be used to solve exactly or approximately even large instances. http://math.uwaterloo.ca/tsp/index.html
------
A mixture of Gaussians can be represented as a weighted points cloud (actually a measure) over the mean/covariance domain. Mixture fitting is a non-convex optimization problem. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mixture_model…
------
Comparing 2D linear interpolation methods of order 0, 1 and 3. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multivariate_interpolation…
------
« Metaballs » are levelsets of mixtures of radial basis functions, which generate blobby lava-lamp-like behaviors.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metaballs https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Blinn… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lava_lamp
------
Burgers’ equation is one of the simplest nonlinear partial differential equations, with solutions exhibiting shocks. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Burgers%27_equation…
------
Fourier approximation of a cat. https://xkcd.com/26/

------
The Wigner-Ville distribution mimics a probability distribution on the space-frequency plane. Useful to define the instantaneous frequency of a signal as the conditional expectation of frequencies. Suffers from interferences. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wigner_distribution_function…
------
Multilayer perceptrons with 1 hidden layer approximate functions using sums of ridge functions. Approximation rates have been stated by Andrew Barron. http://stat.yale.edu/~arb4/publications_files/UniversalApproximationBoundsForSuperpositionsOfASigmoidalFunction.pdf…

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haar_wavelet…

The farthest point sampling is a greedy algorithm which asymptotically samples from a uniform density defined by a distance (e.g. geodesic). Defines a Delone set. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Farthest-first_traversal… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delone_set
------

Fun (...) fact: the figure was generated backwards: from fX and fY, the joint distribution f is computed as the solution of an entropic regularized Optimal Transport (aka Schrodinger's problem).
------
A much simpler approach (but less pleasing visually) would be to take f(x,y)=fX(x)fY(y) (corresponding to the limit of infinite entropic regularization, ie infinite temperature of the gaz for Schrodinger, or independent random variables for probabilists).

Eigenfaces are singular vectors of an image dataset. A principal components analysis is applied to reduce dimensionality and perform face recognition. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eigenface
------
From a color image to its color palette. This is the empirical distribution of the image’s pixels, in 3-D RGB space. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Color_histogram… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RGB_color_space…
------
Oldies but goldies: Marcelo Bertalmio, Guillermo Sapiro, Vincent Caselles et Coloma Ballester, Image Inpainting, 2000. Influential paper on « inpainting » using PDE-based methods. https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inpainting https://upf.edu/-mbertalmio/bertalmi.pdf…
------
Metaballs is defined as the level set of a sum of radial functions. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metaballs
------
The Wasserstein distance over Gaussians defines the so-called Bures metric, which is used extensively to compare quantum states. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bures_metric…
------
Oldies but goldies: J. Portilla and E. Simoncelli. A Parametric Texture Model based on Joint Statistics of Complex Wavelet Coefficients, 2000. Showed that iteratively imposing statistical constraints on wavelet coefficients generates natural textures. http://cns.nyu.edu/~lcv/texture/
------
Voronoi diagrams can be defined over general metric spaces, for instance using l^p norms. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voronoi_diagram…
------
Reverse mode automatic differentiation computes the gradient with approximately the same cost as evaluating the function itself.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automatic_differentiation…
------
Oldies but goldies: Stephen Smale, On gradient dynamical systems, 1961. The Morse-Smale complex segment the space in cells where integral curves of a gradient fields joins stationary points of the fields. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morse%E2%80%93Smale_system…
------
Poisson disk process exhibits blue noise power spectrum which is ideal for sampling. Poisson process exhibits clustering (white noise). Hexagonal grid suffers from periodicity (spiky spectrum) which results in aliasing. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supersampling#Poisson_disc… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Point_process…
------
The color palette of an image is the 3D empirical distribution of the pixels. Optimal transport allows one to interpolate between palettes. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palette_(computing)… https://optimaltransport.github.io
------
Oldies but goldies: A. Buades, B. Coll, J-M. Morel, A review of image denoising algorithms, with a new one, 2005. Non-local means computes an adaptive filtering by comparing patches in images. Started a whole field of research. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-local_means…
------
Subdivision schemes are simple and convenient way to define and manipulate smooth curves and surfaces. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subdivision_surface…
------
Shepard interpolation is a surprisingly simple multi-dimensional interpolation method. It uses singular radial basis functions inversely proportional to the distances to the samples. Nearest neighbor interpolation is the limit case. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inverse_distance_weighting…
------
A joint distribution encodes the dependencies between its two marginal distributions (here in the simple case of a density with respect to a product of measures). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marginal_distribution…
------
Fun (...) fact: the figure was generated backwards: from fX and fY, the joint distribution f is computed as the solution of an entropic regularized Optimal Transport (aka Schrodinger's problem).
------
A much simpler approach (but less pleasing visually) would be to take f(x,y)=fX(x)fY(y) (corresponding to the limit of infinite entropic regularization, ie infinite temperature of the gaz for Schrodinger, or independent random variables for probabilists).
------
Oldies but goldies: C. Shannon, 1949, Communication in the presence of noise. 
States the Nyquist–Shannon sampling theorem. Explains the aliasing of signals. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nyquist%E2%80%93Shannon_sampling_theorem…
------
Brenier’s theorem solves the long standing question of existence of an optimal transport map, under the hypothesis that the source distribution is non-singular (has a density).  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transportation_theory_(mathematics)…

Oldies but goldies: D. Huffman, A Method for the Construction of Minimum-Redundancy Codes, 1952. Introduced an algorithm computing the optimal variable length code. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Huffman_coding…
------
This simple formula shows that bilinear forms (e.g. dot products) and quadratic forms (e.g. norms^2) are in bijection. This is however not true in characteristic 2 (i.e. if 1+1=0), in this case, there are "more" bilinear forms. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Characteristic_(algebra)…
------
Finding the optimal denoising parameter is a bias-variance tradeoff. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bias%E2%80%93variance_tradeoff… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noise_reduction… http://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/gpeyre/numerical-tours/blob/master/python/denoisingsimp_2b_linear_image.ipynb…
------
Oldies but goldies: L Page, S Brin, The PageRank citation ranking: Bringing order to the web, 1999. Page rank is the leading eigenvector of a stochastic matrix. Can be computed efficiently for sparse graph using power iterations. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PageRank
------
The Delaunay triangulation is the dual of the Voronoi diagram. The most fundamental tool of computational geometry. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delaunay_triangulation… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voronoi_diagram… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computational_geometry…
------
This is probably not so surprising, but Fenchel-Rockafellar duality is invariant by linear changes of variables.
------
Oldies but goldies: R. Hartley, A More Symmetrical Fourier Analysis Applied to Transmission Problems, 1942. The Hartley orthogonal matrix is associated to cas=cos+sin function. Defines an involutive real-valued Fourier-like transform. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discrete_Hartley_transform…
------
Heat diffusion vs. wave equation on a surface. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laplace%E2%80%93Beltrami_operator…

Every square matrix is the product of two symmetric matrices! https://tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/00029890.1986.11971855…
------
The minimum spanning tree of points for the Euclidean distance is a sub-graph of the Delaunay triangulation. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euclidean_minimum_spanning_tree…
------
Oldies but goldies: K. Arrow, L. Hurwicz and H. Uzawa, Studies in linear and non-linear programming, 1958. Introduces a primal-dual algorithm (often called «Arrow-Hurwicz») to solve convex-concave saddle points (for instance games with mixed strategies) using proximal operators.
------
The Laplacian of a graph is a semi-definite positive operator which mimics second order differences along the graph’s edges. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laplacian_matrix…
------
Oldies but goldies: Donald L. Pieper, The kinematics of manipulators under computer control, 1968. Inverse kinematics is an ill-posed inverse problem (non-unique solution) and it is solved here by gradient descent (which favors minimal displacements).  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inverse_kinematics…
------
The fact that the animation is smooth reflects that the numerical solver has an implicit bias. It does not pick a random solution at each frame, so that it creates a smooth evolution.
------
If d is a distance, then d^p for 0<p<1 is its snowflake distance. Naming bc of the von Koch fractal which is a snowflake space associated to the Hausdorff measure of the curve. https://emis.de/journals/AASF/Vol30/tyson.pdf…
------
Oldies but goldies: E. Schrödinger. Sur la théorie relativiste de l’électron et l’interprétation de la mécanique, 1932. Shrödinger problem defines an interpolation between two distributions using Brownian bridges. 0 temperature is Optimal Transport. https://hal.archives-ouvertes.fr/hal-00849930/document…
------
The A^* heuristic path planing algorithm reduces the search space of Dijkstra using a heuristic. A valid heuristic should not overestimate the distance to the target. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A*_search_algorithm…
------

Oldies but goldies: E. Hopf, The partial differential equation [...], 1950. J. D. Cole, On a quasi-linear [...], 1951. The Hopf-Cole transform turns non-linear advection/diffusion (Burgers, Eikonale) into linear equations (Heat, Poisson). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Burgers%27_equation#Solution_of_viscous_Burgers'_equation…
------
Simplicial homology defines discrete derivatives (boundary operators) between simplicies of increasing dimensions. Betty numbers are topological invariants which are associated to ranks of these maps. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simplicial_homology…
------
Oldies but goldies: Stéphane Mallat, A theory for multiresolution signal decomposition: the wavelet representation,1989. Introduces the discrete wavelet transform, which is a linear time algorithm iterating low pass and high pass filterings.
------
I think I already tweeted about this, but this paper of Hashimoto, Gifford and Jaakkola on learning Wasserstein flows is one of my all time favorite on Optimal Transport for ML. It had a big impact on me. https://proceedings.mlr.press/v48/hashimoto16.html…
------
Generalized linear heat diffusion are obtained by replacing the Laplacian by a fractional Laplacian. Steepest descent minimization of the Sobolev norm of the function. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fractional_Laplacian…
------
Not to be confounded with the p-Laplacian, which is non-linear!
------
Non-linear heat diffusions are obtained as gradient flows of L^p Dirichlet energies. 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/P-Laplacian…
------

Chaikin’s corner cutting is the simplest and the most famous approximating curve subdivision scheme. Generates quadratic splines. http://nbviewer.org/github/gpeyre/numerical-tours/blob/master/matlab/meshwav_1_subdivision_curves.ipynb…
------
Oldies but goldies: S. Kaczmarz, Angenäherte Auflösung von Systemen linearer Gleichungen, 1937. Kaczmarz’s algorithm corresponds to the iterative projection on the hyper-space defined by the columns. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kaczmarz_method…
------
Warping from an arbitrary domain and a disk can be achieved by Tutte parameterization method. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tutte_embedding… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diffeomorphism…

Oldies but goldies: E. Hopf, The partial differential equation [...], 1950. J. D. Cole, On a quasi-linear [...], 1951. The Hopf-Cole transform turns non-linear advection/diffusion (Burgers, Eikonale) into linear equations (Heat, Poisson). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Burgers%27_equation#Solution_of_viscous_Burgers'_equation…
------
Simplicial homology defines discrete derivatives (boundary operators) between simplicies of increasing dimensions. Betty numbers are topological invariants which are associated to ranks of these maps. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simplicial_homology…
------
Oldies but goldies: Stéphane Mallat, A theory for multiresolution signal decomposition: the wavelet representation,1989. Introduces the discrete wavelet transform, which is a linear time algorithm iterating low pass and high pass filterings.
------
I think I already tweeted about this, but this paper of Hashimoto, Gifford and Jaakkola on learning Wasserstein flows is one of my all time favorite on Optimal Transport for ML. It had a big impact on me. https://proceedings.mlr.press/v48/hashimoto16.html…
------
Generalized linear heat diffusion are obtained by replacing the Laplacian by a fractional Laplacian. Steepest descent minimization of the Sobolev norm of the function. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fractional_Laplacian…
------
Not to be confounded with the p-Laplacian, which is non-linear!
------
Non-linear heat diffusions are obtained as gradient flows of L^p Dirichlet energies. 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/P-Laplacian…
------
Oldies but goldies: W. Heisenberg, Ueber den anschaulichen Inhalt der quantentheoretischen Kinematik und Mechanik, 1923. Heisenberg uncertainty principle states that a function cannot be well concentrated both in space and in frequency.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uncertainty_principle…
------
Non-linear heat diffusions are obtained as gradient flows of L^p Dirichlet energies. 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/P-Laplacian…
------
It is also possible to consider Wassertein flows of these energies in place of L^2 (which lead to admittedly quite hardcore PDEs).
------
Oldies but goldies: J. H. Friedman and W. Stuetzle, Projection pursuit regression, 1981. The simplest greedy algorithm to compute a sparse approximation of a vector within a dictionary. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Projection_pursuit_regression…
------
Oldies but goldies: Max Wertheimer, Untersuchungen zur lehre der gestalt, 1923. Lays the fundation of Gestalt theory, as a set of basic grouping principles to explain human vision and optical illusions. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gestalt_psychology… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Principles_of_grouping… http://math-info.univ-paris5.fr/~moisan/iam34.php…
------
Regular 1:4 subdivision defines a multi-scale analysis on meshes. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subdivision_surface…
------
Oldies but goldies: Lars Onsager, Crystal statistics. I. A two-dimensional model with an order-disorder transition, 1944. Gives the analytic expression for the phase transition of the 2D Ising model on a square lattice. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Square_lattice_Ising_model…
------
Parametric surfaces embedded in Euclidean space define  Riemannian manifolds associated to the first fundamental form. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_fundamental_form…

The phase of the Fourier transform matters. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phase_retrieval…

Oldies but goldies: R Cook, Stochastic sampling in computer graphics, 1986. Introduces Poisson disk distribution as an optimal stochastic sampling strategy for graphics, with applications to Monte-Carlo, raytracing, desaliasing, halftoning, etc. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supersampling#Poisson_disc…
------
p-Fractional Laplacian are (possibly non-local) differential operators computed using Fourier transforms. For p=2 one retrieves the standard Laplacian.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fractional_Laplacian…
------
Oldies but goldies: M. Aharon, M. Elad, A. Bruckstein, K-SVD: An Algorithm for Designing Overcomplete Dictionaries for Sparse Representation, 2006. The most popular dictionary learning method. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/K-SVD
------
Particle system is a Lagrangian way to minimize energies over measures. For entropy and linear functionals, this approximates Fokker–Planck equations. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fokker%E2%80%93Planck_equation…
------
With Thibault and François-Xavier we wrote a review/tutorial on Unbalanced Optimal Transport, including extensions such as Gromov-Wasserstein. https://arxiv.org/abs/2211.08775

Oldies but goldies: R. Tarjan, Dynamic trees as search trees via Euler tours, applied to the network simplex algorithm, 1997. Detailed an optimal network simplex algorithm. 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_simplex_algorithm…
------
Low frequency approximation of discontinuous functions generates Gibbs oscillations. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gibbs_phenomenon…
------
Histogram equalization is 1-D optimal transport. Linearly interpolating the sorted values is Robert McCann's displacement interpolation, aka the OT geodesic. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Histogram_equalization… http://math.toronto.edu/mccann/

------
Optimal Transport (OT) imposes the exact conservation of mass, which is often problematic. Unbalanced OT relaxes this constraint and makes OT robust to outliers and noise. 1/7
------
The same idea can be applied to study the training of two layers perceptrons. For ReLu networks, classical gradient training (i.e. Wasserstein flow) is actually equivalent to an unbalanced flow on the sphere! 6/7
https://francisbach.com/gradient-descent-for-wide-two-layer-neural-networks-implicit-bias/…
