Another amazing application of unbalanced OT is for trajectory inference from single cells genomics, a recent revolution in biology. 7/7 https://broadinstitute.github.io/wot/tutorial/
------
The uncertainty principle states that a function cannot be well concentrated both in space and in frequency.  
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uncertainty_principle…
------
To clarify: the displayed functions are modulated Gaussian ("Gabor functions"), which are the functions for which the inequality is an equality. The box displayed their support over the space/frequency plane (the area of which is thus minimal).
------
Oldies but goldies: Tibor Radó, Uber den Begriff der Riemannschen Flache, 1925. Shows that all compact surfaces can be triangulated. https://maths.ed.ac.uk/~v1ranick/papers/rado.pdf… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hauptvermutung…
------
Forward stagewise regression (aka matching pursuit) is the simplest greedy algorithm to compute a sparse approximation of a vector within a dictionary. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Projection_pursuit_regression…
------
This algorithm can also be used for theoretical purposes, to show the existence of a neural network with k neurons with approximation error 1/sqrt(k). This is explained in Section VIII of Andrew Barron's paper. http://stat.yale.edu/~arb4/publications_files/UniversalApproximationBoundsForSuperpositionsOfASigmoidalFunction.pdf…
------
Oldies but goldies: Jon Claerbout and Francis Muir, Robust Modeling with Erratic Data, 1973. First appearance of L1 minimisation for the sparse regularization of inverse problems. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sparse_approximation…
------
The Fast Fourier Transform: « the most important numerical algorithm of our lifetime » according to Gilbert Strang. Equivalent to a sparse factorisation of the Fourier matrix. 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fast_Fourier_transform…
------
Oldies but goldies: Peter Burt and Ted Adelson, The Laplacian Pyramid as a Compact Image Code, 1983. The Laplacian pyramid is the ancestor of the wavelet transform. Defines a compact multiscale representation by iterative lowpass/highpass filterings. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pyramid_(image_processing)…
------
Lloyd’s algorithm is the continuous counterpart of k-means. Minimizes the optimal quantization energy, which is an optimal transport distance to free Dirac masses. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lloyd%27s_algorithm… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vector_quantization…
------
To obtain a smooth animation, here I rather do a gradient descent on the discrete measure. This is an "unbalanced" Optimal Transport flow.
------
The geodesic structure of OT is equivalent to doing gradient descent on particles positions. Unbalanced flow corresponds to doing the descent on both positions and mass amplitudes. 4/7
https://arxiv.org/abs/1609.03890
------
Oldies but goldies: AL Hodgkin, AF Huxley, A quantitative description of membrane current and its application to conduction and excitation in nerve, 1952. Mathematical model of creation and propagation of action potentials in neurons. Nobel Prize in 1963. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hodgkin%E2%80%93Huxley_model…
------
For saddle point problems and more general games, explicit stepping can fail to converge. Using an extrapolation steps adresses this issue and converges to a saddle point (Nash equilibrium). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Variational_inequality…
------
Oldies but goldies: M Kass and A Witkin. Analyzing oriented patterns, 1987. Defines the structure tensor, the local covariance matrix field of the gradient vector field. Encodes the local anisotropy of an image.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Structure_tensor…
------
There exists various discrete cosine transform which corresponds to various symmetric boundary conditions. Defines Fourier-like transforms which do not assume periodicity. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discrete_cosine_transform…
------
Oldies but goldies: S. Amari, Differential geometrical methods in statistics, 1985. Defines information geometry and in particular the natural gradient as the canonical way to optimize on parametric family of densities.  https://projecteuclid.org/download/pdf_1/euclid.lnms/1215467059…
------
Hadamard–Rademacher–Walsh transform is the Fourier transform on the group (Z/2Z)^n, and enjoys a N*log(N) fast transform. It is used among other thing in error correcting codes. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hadamard_transform… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walsh_function…
------
Oldies but goldies: George Chaikin, An algorithm for high speed curve generation, 1974. The corner cutting algorithm is the most famous approximating curve subdivision scheme. http://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/gpeyre/numerical-tours/blob/master/matlab/meshwav_1_subdivision_curves.ipynb…
------
Optimal Transport (OT) imposes the exact conservation of mass, which is often problematic. Unbalanced OT relaxes this constraint and makes OT robust to outliers and noise. 1/7
------
The same idea can be applied to study the training of two layers perceptrons. For ReLu networks, classical gradient training (i.e. Wasserstein flow) is actually equivalent to an unbalanced flow on the sphere! 6/7
https://francisbach.com/gradient-descent-for-wide-two-layer-neural-networks-implicit-bias/…
------
Another amazing application of unbalanced OT is for trajectory inference from single cells genomics, a recent revolution in biology. 7/7 https://broadinstitute.github.io/wot/tutorial/
------
K-means++ defines a seeding strategy which is approximately optimal up to a logarithmic factor. Running k-means afterward only marginally improves the quantization error (as opposed to bad seeding). http://ilpubs.stanford.edu:8090/778/1/2006-13.pdf…
------
Oldies but goldies: Johann Radon, About the determination of functions from their integral functions in certain directions, 1917. Introduces the Radon transform and its inverse, which is at the heart of many tomographic imaging technics. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radon_transform…
------

Bertrand Mercier and Daniel Gabay were among the first to give its modern formulation.  http://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/gpeyre/numerical-tours/blob/master/python/ml_2_regression.ipynb…

Interior point methods solves approximately in polynomial time conic programs (linear, quadratic, SDP, etc.). Uses a logarithmic barrier function to define an interior path converging to the solution and successive Newton steps to track this trajectory. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interior_point_method…

The foundation of linear signal processing. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convolution_theorem…

------
The celebrated Iterative Soft Thresholding (ISTA) algorithm to solve the LASSO is a special case of the Forward-Backward algorithm. Bertrand Mercier and Daniel Gabay were among the first to give its modern formulation.  http://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/gpeyre/numerical-tours/blob/master/python/ml_2_regression.ipynb…
------
Oldies but goldies: Henry Wilbraham, On a certain periodic function, 1848.  Discovered the Gibbs phenomenon nearly fifty years before J. Willard Gibbs. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gibbs_phenomenon…
------
Least square is the most fundamental data analysis method. Gauss or Legendre? https://projecteuclid.org/download/pdf_1/euclid.aos/1176345451…
------
Eigenvalues of rank 1 perturbations of random symmetric matrices generate curves, among which a single one exits to infinity, the other one returning to the real axis. This is a spectral «musical game» according to Guillaume Dubach. https://arxiv.org/abs/2108.13694
------
The game is to decide which one is going to explode.
------
Oldies but goldies: Albert Einstein, Über die von der molekularkinetischen Theorie der Wärme geforderte Bewegung von in ruhenden Flüssigkeiten suspendierten Teilchen, 1905. Introduces the Brownian motion. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brownian_motion…
------
Reuleaux polygons and Meissner bodies are particular instances of bodies of constant width. 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reuleaux_triangle…
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reuleaux_tetrahedron…
------
Oldies but goldies: Bregman, The relaxation method of finding the common points of convex sets , 1967. Bregman divergences are convex distance-like functionals which are locally Euclidean. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bregman_divergence…
------
Dithering is the process of converting a real-valued image into a finite number of values (eg binary) image while avoiding periodic patterns, to optimize perceptual quality. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dither
------
Oldies but goldies: H. Helmholtz, Über Integrale der hydrodynamischen Gleichungen, welcher der Wirbelbewegungen entsprechen, 1858.  The Helmholtz-Hodge decomposition splits vectors fields in two orthogonal subspaces: incompressible and irrotational. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helmholtz_decomposition…
------
Fourier approximation of a cat. https://xkcd.com/26/
------
Oldies but goldies: L. Vietoris, Über den höheren Zusammenhang kompakter Räume und eine Klasse von zusammenhangstreuen Abbildungen, 1927. The Vietoris–Rips is the simplicial complex associated to the epsilon-nearest-neighbor graph. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vietoris%E2%80%93Rips_complex…
------
Interior point methods solves approximately in polynomial time conic programs (linear, quadratic, SDP, etc.). Uses a logarithmic barrier function to define an interior path converging to the solution and successive Newton steps to track this trajectory. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interior_point_method…
------
And using CVXPY is highly recommended!  https://cvxpy.org
------
Oldies but goldies: J. Barnes, P. Hut, A hierarchical O(N log N) force-calculation algorithm, 1986. Evaluate in O(n*log(n)) in place of O(n^2) sums involving long-range interaction kernels. Simpler but less accurate than Fast Multipole. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barnes%E2%80%93Hut_simulation…
------
Total variation denoising (Leonid Rudin, Stanley Osher, Emad Fatemi, 92) was studied in theory among other by the mathematician Vicent Caselles who died in 2013. He proved  that it does not create discontinuities but blurs corners. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Total_variation_denoising…
------
Oldies but goldies: B. D. Lucas and T. Kanade, An iterative image registration technique with an application to stereo vision,1981. Solves the optical flow by patch matching, which regularizes the color consistency constraint. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lucas%E2%80%93Kanade_method…
------
The Fourier transform diagonalizes convolution operators aka circulant matrices aka linear operators which commute with translations. 
The foundation of linear signal processing. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convolution_theorem…
------
Oldies but goldies: Klaus Wagner, Über eine Eigenschaft der ebenen Komplexe, 1937. State the basic condition (does not contain K33 and K5 minors) to check planarity of a graph.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wagner%27s_theorem…
------
Joukowsky conformal map: solving airfoil design in the pre-computer era. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joukowsky_transform…
------
Wavelet transform of an image iterates low pass and high pass filtering along horizontal and vertical directions. Wavelet coefficients are the high-pass ones. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wavelet_transform…

Oldies but goldies: E.Candès and D.Donoho. New tight frames of curvelets and optimal representations of objects with piecewise-C2 singularities 2002. Define generalized wavelets with a parabolic width/length ratio, to optimally compress cartoon images. http://curvelet.org
------
The natural gradient is the gradient according to the Riemannian structure on densities defined by the Fisher information metric. It is invariant to reparameterization, which makes natural gradient descent intrinsic to the geometry of the densities. https://projecteuclid.org/download/pdf_1/euclid.lnms/1215467059…

Vizualizing the attraction bassin of Newton’s method on polynomial as the roots moves. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newton_fractal…
------
Oldies but goldies: Michael Kass, Andrew Witkin, and Demetri Terzopoulos. Snakes: Active contour models, 1987. Active contour performs image segmentation by evolving a curve minimizing an energy pulling the curve toward contours. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Active_contour_model…
------
Eulerian (image, grid, finite elements, finite volumes, etc) vs Lagrangian (particles system) discretization of measures/densities. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Particle_system… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lagrangian_and_Eulerian_specification_of_the_flow_field… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuum_mechanics#Kinematics:_deformation_and_motion…
------
Oldies but goldies: Michel Goemans and David Williamson, Improved approximation algorithms for maximum cut and satisfiability problems using semidefinite programming, 1995. A 0.879-approximation of the NP-hard MAX-CUT problem using SDP relaxation and a randomized thresholding.
------
Filtering complex vectors defines a sequence of polygons. Convergence is governed by Fourier spectrum. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Filter_(signal_processing)…
------
Oldies but goldies: J Burgers, A mathematical model illustrating the theory of turbulence, 1948. Burgers’ equation is the prototypical non-linear advection/diffusion equation, which develops shocks. Toy model for fluid dynamics or traffic flows. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Burgers%27_equation…
------
The proximal point algorithm is the simplest non-smooth optimization method. While often intractable, it is the basis for many other efficient proximal splitting methods (FB, DR, ADMM, Dykstra, etc). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proximal_operator…
------
Oldies but goldies: E. W.  Dijkstra, A note on two problems in connexion with graphs, 1959. Dijkstra’s algorithm computes the geodesic distance on a graph in O(n*log(n)) operations using a front propagation algorithm. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dijkstra%27s_algorithm…
------
Frechet, Gumbel and Weibull distributions are extreme value distributions which are limit distributions of the maximum a large number of random variables.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fisher%E2%80%93Tippett%E2%80%93Gnedenko_theorem… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generalized_extreme_value_distribution…
------
Oldies but goldies: E.Candès and D.Donoho. New tight frames of curvelets and optimal representations of objects with piecewise-C2 singularities 2002. Define generalized wavelets with a parabolic width/length ratio, to optimally compress cartoon images. http://curvelet.org
------
The natural gradient is the gradient according to the Riemannian structure on densities defined by the Fisher information metric. It is invariant to reparameterization, which makes natural gradient descent intrinsic to the geometry of the densities. https://projecteuclid.org/download/pdf_1/euclid.lnms/1215467059…
------
Oldies but goldies: Paul De Casteljau, Courbes à pôles, 1959. De Casteljau’s algorithm defines a subdivision’s algorithm to evaluate Bezier’s curves. It revolutionised computer aided geometric design. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De_Casteljau%27s_algorithm…
------
Linearly interpolating matrices produces intriguing interpolations of the eigenvalues.
------
A special case is when interpolating companion matrices of the polynomials associated to the roots, which corresponds to interpolating their coefficients.
------
Interpolating linearly polynomials of a fixed degree defines an interpolation between their roots. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vieta%27s_formulas…
------
k-nearest neighbors is the baseline non-parametric regression and classification method. Increasing k smoothes the estimator. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/K-nearest_neighbors_algorithm… http://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/gpeyre/numerical-tours/blob/master/python/ml_1_pca_nn.ipynb…
------
Oldies but goldies: Bui Tuong Phong, Illumination for computer generated pictures, 1975. Phong shading is the most popular empirical model of illumination which includes specular effects. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phong_reflection_model…
------
Oldies but goldies: J.L. Walsh, A closed set of normal orthogonal functions, 1923. Defines the Hadamard–Rademacher–Walsh ortho-basis, which is the Fourier transform on the group (Z/2Z)^n. Used to define error correcting codes. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hadamard_transform… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walsh_function…
------
The Fisher-Tippett-Gnedenko theorem is the central limit theorem for the maximum of variables. Limit distribution can only be either Frechet, Gumbel or Weibull.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fisher%E2%80%93Tippett%E2%80%93Gnedenko_theorem… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generalized_extreme_value_distribution…
------

Determinantal (resp permanental) processes are repulsive (resp. attractive) point processes.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Determinantal_point_process…
------
1D optimal transport interpolation corresponds to interpolating the inverse cumulative functions (the quantile function). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cumulative_distribution_function#Inverse_distribution_function_(quantile_function)…
------
Many numerical schemes (PDEs, optimization, etc.) can be applied on 3D meshes and voxels. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polygon_mesh… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voxel
------
On non-convex problems, alternating projections is often stuck in local minima while Douglas-Rachord works better.  In phase retrieval, alternating projection is Gerchberg–Saxton while DR is Fienup algorithm. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gerchberg%E2%80%93Saxton_algorithm… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phase_retrieval… http://www4.ncsu.edu/~pcombet/josa1.pdf…
------
Phase retrieval problem is recovering an image from amplitude of Fourier transform and constraint on support. Solution might be unstable and hard to find. Popular methods leverage iterative projections but might fail to converge because of non-convexity. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phase_retrieval…
------
Oldies but goldies: Joachim Weickert, Coherence-enhancing diffusion filtering, 1999. Introduced tensor-driven anisotropic diffusion as a tool for image enhancement. His book on PDE for imaging is amazing, and was his PhD thesis. https://mia.uni-saarland.de/weickert/Papers/book.pdf…

The Riccati equation XAX=B is surprisingly simple to solve on the set of positive matrices. Among other things, useful to define the optimal transport between two Gaussians. Appears also in quantum mechanics. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algebraic_Riccati_equation…
------
Here X is actually the Optimal Transport between the two Gaussians.

Difference of convex (DC) programming are non-convex problem enjoying a nice duality theory and thus a simple optimization algorithm. http://lita.univ-lorraine.fr/~lethi/index.php/dca.html… https://ceremade.dauphine.fr/~carlier/toland.pdf…
------
Oldies but goldies: F. Hausdorff, Der Wertworrat einer Bilinearform, 1919. Proves the result conjectured by Toeplitz that the numerical range is convex. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Numerical_range…
------
The dots are the eigenvalues. For a normal matrix, the numerical range is the convex enveloppe of these points.
------
Determinantal (resp permanental) processes are repulsive (resp. attractive) point processes.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Determinantal_point_process…
------
1D optimal transport interpolation corresponds to interpolating the inverse cumulative functions (the quantile function). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cumulative_distribution_function#Inverse_distribution_function_(quantile_function)…
------
Many numerical schemes (PDEs, optimization, etc.) can be applied on 3D meshes and voxels. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polygon_mesh… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voxel
------
On non-convex problems, alternating projections is often stuck in local minima while Douglas-Rachord works better.  In phase retrieval, alternating projection is Gerchberg–Saxton while DR is Fienup algorithm. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gerchberg%E2%80%93Saxton_algorithm… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phase_retrieval… http://www4.ncsu.edu/~pcombet/josa1.pdf…
------
Phase retrieval problem is recovering an image from amplitude of Fourier transform and constraint on support. Solution might be unstable and hard to find. Popular methods leverage iterative projections but might fail to converge because of non-convexity. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phase_retrieval…
------
Oldies but goldies: Joachim Weickert, Coherence-enhancing diffusion filtering, 1999. Introduced tensor-driven anisotropic diffusion as a tool for image enhancement. His book on PDE for imaging is amazing, and was his PhD thesis. https://mia.uni-saarland.de/weickert/Papers/book.pdf…
------
Exponential families hybridize convex analysis and statistics. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exponential_family…
------
Oldies but goldies: M. Turk and A. Pentland, Face recognition using eigenfaces, 1991. Uses principal component analysis to reduce dimensionality and perform face recognition. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eigenface
------
The Riccati equation XAX=B is surprisingly simple to solve on the set of positive matrices. Among other things, useful to define the optimal transport between two Gaussians. Appears also in quantum mechanics. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algebraic_Riccati_equation…
------
Here X is actually the Optimal Transport between the two Gaussians.
------
Support Vector Machine (Vapnik, Chervonenkis, Cortes) performs classification by minimizing the separation margin between the two classes.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Support_vector_machine…
------
Oldies but goldies: J. B. Kruskal, On the shortest spanning subtree of a graph and the traveling salesman problem, 1956. A greedy algorithm to compute the minimum spanning tree of a graph. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kruskal%27s_algorithm…
------
Phase retrieval problem is recovering an image from amplitude of Fourier transform and constraint on support. Solution might be unstable and hard to find. Popular methods leverage iterative projections but might fail to converge because of non-convexity. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phase_retrieval…
------
Beware that on this example you have to watch the animation to the end to observe that Fienup is able to perfectly recover the original image! This somehow shows the superiority of Douglas-Rachford with respect to iterative projections in the non convex case.
------
Oldies but goldies: L. B. Lucy, An iterative technique for the rectification of observed distributions, 1974. Richardson–Lucy is the basic algorithm for deconvolution under positivity constraints. https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richardson%E2%80%93Lucy_deconvolution…
------
k-nearest neighbors is the baseline non-parametric regression and classification method. Increasing k smoothes the estimator. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/K-nearest_neighbors_algorithm… http://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/gpeyre/numerical-tours/blob/master/python/ml_1_pca_nn.ipynb…
------
Oldies but goldies: G. Cybenko, Approximations by superpositions of sigmoidal functions, 1989. Proves that 1 hidden layer perceptrons can approximate arbitrary continuous functions using a large enough number of neurons. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universal_approximation_theorem… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multilayer_perceptron…
------
Functions can be decomposed as the sum of a convex and a concave function on compact domains. In 1D, it can be done in a « canonical » way using the positive/negative part of the second derivative.  https://msp.org/pjm/1959/9-3/pjm-v9-n3-p09-s.pdf…

Oldies but goldies: McCann, A convexity principle for interacting gases, 1998. Introduces geodesic interpolation using optimal transport. Shows convexity of entropy functions with countless implications & applications.  https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-540-71050-9_15… https://optimaltransport.github.io
------
Vietoris–Rips and Čech complexes are fundamental simplicial complexes constructed from the nearest-neighbor graph. Cech is the nerve, is computationally more expensive but has the correct homology. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vietoris%E2%80%93Rips_complex… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cech_complex…
------
Oldies but goldies: Hilbert, Über die stetige Abbildung einer Linie auf ein Flächenstück, 1891. Defines a continuous map from a segment to a square through an iterative refinement process. Often used to store and traverse 2D arrays. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space-filling_curve… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hilbert_curve…
------
Gaussian scale mixtures defines heavy-tail distributions by combining Gaussian distributions with varying variances. A particular case is the student-t. https://papers.nips.cc/paper/1750-scale-mixtures-of-gaussians-and-the-statistics-of-natural-images.pdf…
------
Oldies but goldies: Gordon, Bender,Herman, Algebraic reconstruction techniques (ART) for three-dimensional electron microscopy and x-ray photography, 1970. ART is equivalent to Kaczmarz’s iterations. Popular to solve inverse problems in imaging. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algebraic_reconstruction_technique…
------
QR algorithm is a gem of numerical algebra: for a symmetric input, also computes the eigenvectors by multiplying the Q factors (here shows Fourier eigenvectors of a convolution)! https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/QR_algorithm…

Oldies but goldies: Reeb, Sur les points singuliers d’une forme de Pfaff complètement intégrable ou d’une fonction numérique, 1946. The Reeb graph of a function is the graph of level sets ordered by inclusion. Used in topological data analysis. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reeb_graph
------
Stone-Weierstrass theorem generalizes polynomial approximation to sub-algebra of continuous functions. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stone%E2%80%93Weierstrass_theorem…
------
An example of application is to prove density of "polynomials" of measures in the space of functions continuous for the convergence in law. These are mappings from a measure toward a tensorized integral (interaction functional). It's Theorem 2 of https://arxiv.org/abs/1811.07429
------
And one can restrict k to be a polynomial, and use Stone-Weierstrass twice! If the mu are dirac masses, this gives back the classical Weierstrass result on polynomial.
------
Oldies but goldies: K. Levenberg, A Method for the Solution of Certain Non-Linear Problems in Least Squares, 1944. Levenberg-Marquardt is a method of choice for non-linear least-squares, replacing Newton's Hessian by the Jacobian term only.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Levenberg%E2%80%93Marquardt_algorithm…
------

Metropolis-Hasting is a simple way to sample from a density known only up to a constant. Defines a Markov chains whose stationary distribution is the target one. [updated version] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metropolis%E2%80%93Hastings_algorithm…
------
Convergence of random vectors comes with lots of flavors! 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convergence_of_random_variables…
------
Oldies but goldies: McCann, A convexity principle for interacting gases, 1998. Introduces geodesic interpolation using optimal transport. Shows convexity of entropy functions with countless implications & applications.  https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-540-71050-9_15… https://optimaltransport.github.io
------
Vietoris–Rips and Čech complexes are fundamental simplicial complexes constructed from the nearest-neighbor graph. Cech is the nerve, is computationally more expensive but has the correct homology. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vietoris%E2%80%93Rips_complex… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cech_complex…
------
Oldies but goldies: Hilbert, Über die stetige Abbildung einer Linie auf ein Flächenstück, 1891. Defines a continuous map from a segment to a square through an iterative refinement process. Often used to store and traverse 2D arrays. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space-filling_curve… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hilbert_curve…
------
Gaussian scale mixtures defines heavy-tail distributions by combining Gaussian distributions with varying variances. A particular case is the student-t. https://papers.nips.cc/paper/1750-scale-mixtures-of-gaussians-and-the-statistics-of-natural-images.pdf…
------
Oldies but goldies: Gordon, Bender,Herman, Algebraic reconstruction techniques (ART) for three-dimensional electron microscopy and x-ray photography, 1970. ART is equivalent to Kaczmarz’s iterations. Popular to solve inverse problems in imaging. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algebraic_reconstruction_technique…
------
QR algorithm is a gem of numerical algebra: for a symmetric input, also computes the eigenvectors by multiplying the Q factors (here shows Fourier eigenvectors of a convolution)! https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/QR_algorithm…
------
Oldies but goldies: Reeb, Sur les points singuliers d’une forme de Pfaff complètement intégrable ou d’une fonction numérique, 1946. The Reeb graph of a function is the graph of level sets ordered by inclusion. Used in topological data analysis. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reeb_graph
------
Stone-Weierstrass theorem generalizes polynomial approximation to sub-algebra of continuous functions. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stone%E2%80%93Weierstrass_theorem…
------
An example of application is to prove density of "polynomials" of measures in the space of functions continuous for the convergence in law. These are mappings from a measure toward a tensorized integral (interaction functional). It's Theorem 2 of https://arxiv.org/abs/1811.07429
------
And one can restrict k to be a polynomial, and use Stone-Weierstrass twice! If the mu are dirac masses, this gives back the classical Weierstrass result on polynomial.
------
Oldies but goldies: K. Levenberg, A Method for the Solution of Certain Non-Linear Problems in Least Squares, 1944. Levenberg-Marquardt is a method of choice for non-linear least-squares, replacing Newton's Hessian by the Jacobian term only.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Levenberg%E2%80%93Marquardt_algorithm…
------
The case tau=0 corresponds to the Gauss-Newton algorithm.
------
Which is also the natural gradient decent for the squared Euclidean loss, where J^T J is often called the Fisher information matrix. https://agustinus.kristia.de/techblog/2018/03/14/natural-gradient/…
------
Implicit stepping is more stable to converge to saddle points. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Explicit_and_implicit_methods…
------
Oldies but goldies: W. Fenchel, On conjugate convex functions, 1949. The Legendre-Fenchel transform extends the Legendre transform to arbitrary dimensions.  |x|^2/2 is the only fixed point of the transform. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Legendre_transformation…
------
Brunn-Minkowski inequality is one of the fundamental inequalities in convex geometry, which generalizes the isoperimetric inequality.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brunn%E2%80%93Minkowski_theorem…
https://terrytao.wordpress.com/tag/brunn-minkowski-inequality/…
------
Training a multi-layer perceptron for classification. A large enough number of neurons captures arbitrary complex decision boundaries. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multilayer_perceptron…
------
Boltzmann transport equation describes the mean field limit of a growing number of evolving particles with a decreasing radius. Models gaz evolution. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boltzmann_equation…
------
For those interested, I found the review by Villani to be *extremely* well written https://cedricvillani.org/sites/dev/files/old_images/2012/07/B01.Handbook.pdf…
------
Oldies but goldies: N Metropolis, A Rosenbluth, M Rosenbluth, A Teller, E Teller, Equation of State Calculations by Fast Computing Machines, 1953. The (wrongly attributed …) Metropolis-Hasting algorithm samples from a density known only up to a constant. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_State_Calculations_by_Fast_Computing_Machines…

------
Oldies but goldies: Pietro Perona and Jitendra Malik, Scale-space and edge detection using anisotropic diffusion, 1987. Introduces anisotropic diffusion, which uses a space-varying conductivity to slow down the diffusion near edges. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anisotropic_diffusion…
------
Anisotropic diffusion is when the diffusivity is defined via a tensor and not just a scalar as in Perona-Malik
------
Oldies but goldies: Joachim Weickert, Coherence-enhancing diffusion filtering, 1999. Introduced tensor-driven anisotropic diffusion as a tool for image enhancement. His book on PDE for imaging is amazing, and was his PhD thesis. https://mia.uni-saarland.de/weickert/Papers/book.pdf…
------
And the world-expert / godfather of anisotropic filtering is David Tschumperlé who develops with people at GREYC 
@gmic_eu
, see for instance: https://hal.archives-ouvertes.fr/hal-00332800/document…
------
One could argue that it is actually a (space-varying) *isotropic* diffusion...
------
Kantorovitch formulation of Optimal Transport is a linear program, and is a generalization of the linear assignment problem. It is a special case of min-cost flow linear problem on a bipartite graph. The associated polytope has many properties https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transportation_theory_(mathematics)… .
------

------
The Parzen-Rosenblatt window estimator approximates a probability density using a sum of kernel functions centered as the samples. This corresponds to convolving the empirical measure with a smoothing kernel. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kernel_density_estimation…
------
Oldies but goldies: Hubel, D. H.; Wiesel, T. N., Receptive fields, binocular interaction and functional architecture in the cat's visual cortex, 1962. Describes the organisation of the visual cortex using oriented filters. Nobel prize in 1981.  https://youtube.com/watch?v=IOHayh06LJ4…
------
Optimal quantization solves a minimum Optimal Transport projection. Lloyd algorithm computes a stationary point of this non-convex energy (see work by Canas and Rosasco https://arxiv.org/pdf/1209.1077.pdf…)

------
Oldies but goldies: R. Tyrrell Rockafellar, Monotone Operators and the Proximal Point Algorithm, 1976. The proximal point algorithm is a fundamental non-smooth optimization method. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proximal_operator…
------
Oldies but goldies: Andrew Witkin, Scale-space filtering, 1984. Introduces (with J. Koenderink) the notion of scale space, i.e. the multi-scales analysis of signals and images, which is at the heart of many vision architectures. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scale_space…
------
With 
@ZaccharieRamzi
, we re-implemented from scratch an attention layer matching exactly the 
@PyTorch
 implementation. We give all the details here, since it should be useful for others wanting to understand how it works. https://colab.research.google.com/drive/1B46_xM9Ju_noMWd8hdq5aLRin4BoaWmH?usp=sharing…
------
Gibbs distributions are maximum entropy distributions. Used in conjunction with MCMC methods to generate samples close to minimisers of the functional. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gibbs_measure… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_chain_Monte_Carlo…
------
Oldies but goldies: K. Levenberg, A Method for the Solution of Certain Non-Linear Problems in Least Squares, 1944. Levenberg-Marquardt is a method of choice for non-linear least-squares, replacing Newton's Hessian by the Jacobian term only.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Levenberg%E2%80%93Marquardt_algorithm…
------
The case tau=0 corresponds to the Gauss-Newton algorithm.
------
Which is also the natural gradient decent for the squared Euclidean loss, where J^T J is often called the Fisher information matrix. https://agustinus.kristia.de/techblog/2018/03/14/natural-gradient/…
------
Implicit stepping is more stable to converge to saddle points. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Explicit_and_implicit_methods…
------
Oldies but goldies: W. Fenchel, On conjugate convex functions, 1949. The Legendre-Fenchel transform extends the Legendre transform to arbitrary dimensions.  |x|^2/2 is the only fixed point of the transform. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Legendre_transformation…
------
Brunn-Minkowski inequality is one of the fundamental inequalities in convex geometry, which generalizes the isoperimetric inequality.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brunn%E2%80%93Minkowski_theorem…
https://terrytao.wordpress.com/tag/brunn-minkowski-inequality/…
------
Oldies but goldies: William Thomson and Peter Guthrie Tait, Treatise on Natural Philosophy, 1867. Among other things, formalizes the notion of spherical harmonics.  Display here is a random evolution in each space. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spherical_harmonics…
------
Spherical harmonics are the equivalent on the sphere of the Fourier basis. Useful to perform low-frequency approximation of functions. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spherical_harmonics…
------
The circle, semi-circle and  Marčenko–Pastur laws are three simple examples of determinantal processes. https://terrytao.wordpress.com/2009/08/23/determinantal-processes…
------
Oldies but goldies: Pietro Perona and Jitendra Malik, Scale-space and edge detection using anisotropic diffusion, 1987. Introduces anisotropic diffusion, which uses a space-varying conductivity to slow down the diffusion near edges. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anisotropic_diffusion…
------
Anisotropic diffusion is when the diffusivity is defined via a tensor and not just a scalar as in Perona-Malik
------
Oldies but goldies: Joachim Weickert, Coherence-enhancing diffusion filtering, 1999. Introduced tensor-driven anisotropic diffusion as a tool for image enhancement. His book on PDE for imaging is amazing, and was his PhD thesis. https://mia.uni-saarland.de/weickert/Papers/book.pdf…
------
And the world-expert / godfather of anisotropic filtering is David Tschumperlé who develops with people at GREYC 
@gmic_eu
, see for instance: https://hal.archives-ouvertes.fr/hal-00332800/document…
------
One could argue that it is actually a (space-varying) *isotropic* diffusion...
------
Kantorovitch formulation of Optimal Transport is a linear program, and is a generalization of the linear assignment problem. It is a special case of min-cost flow linear problem on a bipartite graph. The associated polytope has many properties https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transportation_theory_(mathematics)… .
------
Oldies but goldies: E. Weiszfeld, Sur le point pour lequel la somme des distances de n points donnés est minimum, 1937. Weiszfeld's algorithm is an iterative least square method to compute geometric medians. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geometric_median#Computation…
------
The Parzen-Rosenblatt window estimator approximates a probability density using a sum of kernel functions centered as the samples. This corresponds to convolving the empirical measure with a smoothing kernel. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kernel_density_estimation…
------
Oldies but goldies: Hubel, D. H.; Wiesel, T. N., Receptive fields, binocular interaction and functional architecture in the cat's visual cortex, 1962. Describes the organisation of the visual cortex using oriented filters. Nobel prize in 1981.  https://youtube.com/watch?v=IOHayh06LJ4…
------
Optimal quantization solves a minimum Optimal Transport projection. Lloyd algorithm computes a stationary point of this non-convex energy (see work by Canas and Rosasco https://arxiv.org/pdf/1209.1077.pdf…)
------
Rosasco being of course 
@lrntzrsc
 himself.
------
Oldies but goldies: R. Tyrrell Rockafellar, Monotone Operators and the Proximal Point Algorithm, 1976. The proximal point algorithm is a fundamental non-smooth optimization method. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proximal_operator…
------
Oldies but goldies: Andrew Witkin, Scale-space filtering, 1984. Introduces (with J. Koenderink) the notion of scale space, i.e. the multi-scales analysis of signals and images, which is at the heart of many vision architectures. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scale_space…
------

 implementation. We give all the details here, since it should be useful for others wanting to understand how it works. https://colab.research.google.com/drive/1B46_xM9Ju_noMWd8hdq5aLRin4BoaWmH?usp=sharing…

------
Oldies but goldies: Hiroaki Sakoe and Seibi Chiba, Dynamic programming algorithm optimization for spoken word recognition, 1978. Dynamic Time Warping aligns two time series by an increasing map. Solved in quadratic time by dynamic programming. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_time_warping…
------
1D Optimal Transport distances between Gaussians is the Euclidean distance on the (mean, standard deviation) 2D plane. https://projecteuclid.org/euclid.ojm/1326291215…
------
Mean value coordinates extend usual barycentric coordinates to arbitrary polygons, including non-convex ones! Defined by Michael Floater in 2003. https://sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0167839603000025… http://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/gpeyre/numerical-tours/blob/master/matlab/meshdeform_4_barycentric.ipynb…
------
Oldies but goldies: R. W. Gerchberg, W. O. Saxton, A practical algorithm for the determination of the phase from image and diffraction plane pictures, 1972. The simplest (but not the best) algorithm for phase retrieval. Computes iterative projections. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gerchberg%E2%80%93Saxton_algorithm…

------
Mirror descent generalizes gradient descent using Bregman geometries. https://blogs.princeton.edu/imabandit/2013/04/16/orf523-mirror-descent-part-iii/…
------
Oldies but goldies: J. P. Boyle and R. L. Dykstra, A method for finding projections onto the intersection of convex sets in Hilbert spaces, 1986. Dykstra’s algorithm is the simplest method to project on the intersection of two convex sets. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dykstra%27s_projection_algorithm…
------
It works for more than two sets. It works for projections according to Bregman divergences. In the case of affine constraints, it corresponds to the iterative projections method (POCS).
------
It still works surprisingly well for non convex constraints. For instance for phase retrieval it is related to Fienup's algorithm.
------
Page rank is the leading eigenvector of a stochastic matrix. Can be computed efficiently for sparse graphs using power iterations. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PageRank
------

------
Nonlinearity matters. Linear diffusion (heat) has non-compactly supported solutions. Non-linear diffusion (porous medium) drives dynamics with compactly supported solutions. The porous medium is the simplest case, studied in details by Otto. https://mis.mpg.de/preprints/1999/preprint1999_8.pdf…
------

http://hhoppe.com/proj/mra/

Nonlinearity matters. Linear diffusion (heat) has non-compactly supported solutions. Non-linear diffusion (porous medium) drives dynamics with compactly supported solutions. The porous medium is the simplest case, studied in details by Otto. https://mis.mpg.de/preprints/1999/preprint1999_8.pdf…
------
Oldies but goldies: Matthias Eck, Tony DeRose, Tom Duchamp, Hugues Hoppe, Michael Lounsbery, Werner Stuetzle, Multiresolution analysis of arbitrary meshes, 1995
http://hhoppe.com/proj/mra/
------
Optimization algorithms come with many flavors depending on the structure of the problem. Smooth vs non-smooth, convex vs non-convex, stochastic vs deterministic, etc. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_optimization…
------
Oldies but goldies: J. B. Kruskal, On the shortest spanning subtree of a graph and the traveling salesman problem, 1956. Computes the minimum spanning tree in n*log(n) operations. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prim%27s_algorithm…
------
The Laplacian pyramid is the ancestor of the wavelet transform. Defines a compact multiscale representation by iterative lowpass/highpass filterings. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pyramid_(image_processing)…
------
Oldies but goldies: Jan Koenderink, The structure of images, 1984. Introduces (with A. Witkin) the notion of scale space, i.e. the multi-scale analysis of signals and images, which is at the heart of many vision architectures. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scale_space…
------
Gibbs distributions are maximum entropy distributions. Used in conjunction with MCMC methods to generate samples close to minimisers of the functional. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gibbs_measure… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_chain_Monte_Carlo…
------
Oldies but goldies: Hiroaki Sakoe and Seibi Chiba, Dynamic programming algorithm optimization for spoken word recognition, 1978. Dynamic Time Warping aligns two time series by an increasing map. Solved in quadratic time by dynamic programming. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_time_warping…
------
1D Optimal Transport distances between Gaussians is the Euclidean distance on the (mean, standard deviation) 2D plane. https://projecteuclid.org/euclid.ojm/1326291215…
------
Mean value coordinates extend usual barycentric coordinates to arbitrary polygons, including non-convex ones! Defined by Michael Floater in 2003. https://sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0167839603000025… http://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/gpeyre/numerical-tours/blob/master/matlab/meshdeform_4_barycentric.ipynb…
------
Oldies but goldies: R. W. Gerchberg, W. O. Saxton, A practical algorithm for the determination of the phase from image and diffraction plane pictures, 1972. The simplest (but not the best) algorithm for phase retrieval. Computes iterative projections. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gerchberg%E2%80%93Saxton_algorithm…
------
The Laplace and the Legendre transforms are related by an exponential change of variables. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laplace_transform… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Legendre_transformation…
------
Oldies but goldies: V. Jarník, M. Kössler, On minimal graphs containing n given points,  1934. The Euclidean Steiner tree looks for the shortest irrigation tree of nodes. This paper proved the main property of this tree, which is hard to compute. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steiner_tree_problem…
------
A reminder that a quick and dirty translation of my book (initially written in French) "The Discrete Algebra of the Fourier Transform" is freely available online. https://mathematical-tours.github.io/daft-sources/DAFT-EN.pdf…
------
I have accumulated ~1K different posts... a good excuse to learn and code from scratch many different things! https://github.com/mathematical-tours/mathematical-tours.github.io/tree/master/tweets-sources/codes…
------
Mirror descent generalizes gradient descent using Bregman geometries. https://blogs.princeton.edu/imabandit/2013/04/16/orf523-mirror-descent-part-iii/…
------
Oldies but goldies: J. P. Boyle and R. L. Dykstra, A method for finding projections onto the intersection of convex sets in Hilbert spaces, 1986. Dykstra’s algorithm is the simplest method to project on the intersection of two convex sets. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dykstra%27s_projection_algorithm…
------
It works for more than two sets. It works for projections according to Bregman divergences. In the case of affine constraints, it corresponds to the iterative projections method (POCS).
------
It still works surprisingly well for non convex constraints. For instance for phase retrieval it is related to Fienup's algorithm.
------
Page rank is the leading eigenvector of a stochastic matrix. Can be computed efficiently for sparse graphs using power iterations. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PageRank
------
Oldies but goldies: A. Brandt, Multi-Level Adaptive Solutions to Boundary-Value Problems, 1977. Introduces the multigrid method, which is the fundamental tool to speed up the convergence of low frenquencies for the resolution of PDEs. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multigrid_method…

The Wasserstein distance is the largest convex function which, once evaluated on Dirac distributions, is equal to the ground distance, W(delta_x,delta_y)=d(x,y).
------
A very nice account for this property by 
@GSavare
 https://cvgmt.sns.it/paper/5594/
------
Oldies but goldies: A. J. Lotka, Contribution to the Theory of Periodic Reaction, 1910. Lotka–Volterra is a non-linear ODE modeling chemical reaction or prey/predator behaviors which exhibits periodic solutions.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lotka%E2%80%93Volterra_equations…
------
Fenchel-Rockafellar duality leverage linear operator in Lagrange duality. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fenchel%27s_duality_theorem… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duality_(optimization)…
------
Oldies but goldies: Yurri Nesterov, A method for solving a convex programming problem with convergence rate O(1/k^2). Improves the 1/k rate of vanilla gradient descent to 1/k^2. https://blogs.princeton.edu/imabandit/2013/04/01/acceleratedgradientdescent/…

The Wasserstein distance is the largest convex function which, once evaluated on Dirac distributions, is equal to the ground distance, W(delta_x,delta_y)=d(x,y).
------
A very nice account for this property by 
@GSavare
 https://cvgmt.sns.it/paper/5594/

Oldies but goldies: William Lorensen, Harvey Cline, Marching Cubes: A high resolution 3D surface construction algorithm, 1987. The standard algorithm to extract iso-curves/surfaces from a discretized image/volume. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marching_squares… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marching_cubes…
------
A very nice notion of "conjugaison" between probability distributions on compact manifolds https://arxiv.org/pdf/0901.1815.pdf… (section 3&4). In 1D is corresponds to inverting the cumulative function, in higher dimension it exchanges points into boundaries of "voronoi" cells.
------
Oldies but goldies: Teofilio Gonzalez, Clustering to minimize the maximum intercluster distance, 1985. Popularized the farthest point sampling greedy algorithm. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Farthest-first_traversal…
------
Reaction-diffusion with spatially varying weights. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reaction%E2%80%93diffusion_system… https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Chemical_Basis_of_Morphogenesis…
------
Oldies but goldies: James Blinn, A Generalization of Algebraic Surface Drawing, 1982. « Metaballs » are levelsets of mixtures of radial basis functions, which generate blobby lava-lamp-like behaviors. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metaballs
------
Birkhoff’s contraction for Hilbert’s metric is a key tool to quantify convergence
of Markov-Chains (Perron-Frobenius). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hilbert_metric…
------
Instead of considering point clouds, an alternative ("softer") way to think of attention mechanisms (at the heart of transformers) is to view them as transporting ("push-forwarding") probability distributions by data-dependent maps.

Stable fluids of Jos Stam is a semi-Lagrangian solver for Navier-Stokes, which was very influential in graphics because of its simplicity and stability. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jos_Stam http://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/gpeyre/numerical-tours/blob/master/python/graphics_5_fluids.ipynb…
------
Oldies but goldies: R. Leibler and S. Kullback, On information and sufficiency, 1951. KL divergence (aka relative entropy) is a Bregman and Csiszar divergence between distributions  and has an information-theoretic interpretation. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kullback%E2%80%93Leibler_divergence…
------
QR algorithm is a gem of numerical algebra: iterative QR decomposition converges to a triangular matrix. Converges to a diagonal matrix for symmetric inputs. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/QR_algorithm…
------
Oldies but goldies: Jean-Jacques Moreau, Proximité et dualité dans un espace hilbertien, 1965.
Moreau-Yosida regularization smoothes a function by inf-convolution. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convex_conjugate#Infimal_convolution…
------
The medial axis (aka skeleton) is the set of points where the distance is not smooth. Used as a shape descriptor in computer vision.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medial_axis… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topological_skeleton…
------
Oldies but goldies: Sarah Frisken Gibson, Using distance maps for accurate surface reconstruction in sampled volumes, 1998. Dual contouring methods usually produce better quality meshes than primal ones. https://people.eecs.berkeley.edu/~jrs/meshpapers/SchaeferWarren2.pdf…
------
Interpolating between implicit equations defines morphings between curves or surfaces.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Implicit_surface#Metamorphoses_of_implicit_surfaces…
------
Oldies but goldies: L. Breiman, J. H. Friedman, R. A. Olshen, and C. J. Stone. Classification and Regression Trees, 1984. Defines structured recursive classification and regression functions. Global optimization is achieved by dynamic programming. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decision_tree_learning…
------
n-ellipses generalize ellipses with n foci. Spectrahedra (hence convex), with algebraic equations of degree less than 2^n. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/N-ellipse https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spectrahedron…
------
Oldies but goldies: C Huygens, Horologium Oscillatorium sive de motu pendulorum ad horologia aptato. 1673. First rigorous study of the motion of the pendulum (he also invented the pendulum clock), showing it is not isochronous. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pendulum_(mathematics)…
------
Projected gradient is the simplest algorithm to perform constrained optimization of a smooth function. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subgradient_method#Projected_subgradient…
------
Oldies but goldies: J. Duchon, Splines minimizing rotation invariant semi-norms in Sobolev spaces, 1976. Thin plate spline is one of the most popular data interpolation methods. Its solution can be written in 2D using the r^2*log(r) radial basis function. https://github.com/dill/duchon-typeset/blob/master/paper.pdf…
------
The space of compact sets in a metric space is a compact set for the Hausdorff metric. Hausdorff convergence is weak and does not preserve topology, dimension, length or path-connectedness. It preserves connectedness and convexity. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hausdorff_distance…
------
Oldies but goldies: Robin Sibson, A vector identity for the Dirichlet tesselation, 1980.
Defines natural neighbor interpolation, generalizing of piecewise linear interpolation to higher dimensions.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_neighbor_interpolation… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robin_Sibson…
------
Moreau’s decomposition generalizes the orthogonal decomposition to general function. It can also be generalized beyond Euclidean space using Bregman divergences in place of Euclidean distance.  
https://hal.archives-ouvertes.fr/hal-01076974/document…
------
A quadratic bezier spline is the enveloppe of regularly spaced lines. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/B%C3%A9zier_curve…

------

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flip_graph

------
MAX-CUT is an NP hard problem. Goemans and Williamson SDP relaxation with randomized thresholding achieves a 0.879-approximation. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maximum_cut… http://www-math.mit.edu/~goemans/PAPERS/maxcut-jacm.pdf…
------

------

Oldies but goldies: Wagner, Bemerkungen zum Vierfarbenproblem, 1936. Later improved by Komuro. Any pair of planar triangulations of n vertices can be connected by O(n) edge flips (despite the exponential number of triangulations) https://eudml.org/doc/146109
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flip_graph
------
SMACOF is the most popular stress minimization algorithm for multidimensional scaling (for dimensionality reduction or shape flattening). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stress_majorization…
------
Oldies but goldies: Tony F. Chan, Luminita A. Vese, Active Contours Without Edges, 2001. The simplest and most celebrated region-based segmentation method. Minimizes a binary Mumford-Shah segmentation functional using the level set method. https://ipol.im/pub/art/2012/g-cv/…
------
The Brachistochrone problem was solved by Bernoulli and is the birth of calculus of variations.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calculus_of_variations… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brachistochrone_curve…
------
Oldies but goldies: B.K.P. Horn and B.G. Schunck, Determining optical flow, 1981. Computes optical flow by a quadratic regularization of the brightness constancy constraint. Solution is obtained by solving a linear system. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horn%E2%80%93Schunck_method…
------
Vornoi cells on a surface define to a geodesic Delaunay triangulation. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triangulation_(topology)#Explicit_methods_of_triangulation… https://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?doid=336154.336221…
------
Oldies but goldies: W. Givens, Computation of Plane Unitary Rotations Transforming a General Matrix to Triangular Form, 1958. The QR decomposition can be computed in a numerically stable way using planar rotation matrices. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Givens_rotation…
------
MAX-CUT is an NP hard problem. Goemans and Williamson SDP relaxation with randomized thresholding achieves a 0.879-approximation. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maximum_cut… http://www-math.mit.edu/~goemans/PAPERS/maxcut-jacm.pdf…
------
Oldies but goldies: L. Greengard and V. Rokhlin, A Fast Algorithm for Particle Simulations, 1987. Evaluates in O(n) in place of O(n^2) sums involving long-range interaction kernels. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fast_multipole_method…
------
POCS, Dykstra and DR often succeed in finding points in the intersection of possibly non-convex sets. Dykstra and DR usually work better.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Projections_onto_convex_sets… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dykstra%27s_projection_algorithm…
------
Oldies but goldies: Maurice G. Cox, The Numerical Evaluation of B-Splines, 1972. Introduced (with De Boor) an efficient algorithm for the evaluation of B-splines, which revolutionized CAGD.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De_Boor%27s_algorithm…
------
Tutte embedding is the solution of a Poisson equation. Iterative resolution is equivalent to a system of masses and springs. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tutte_embedding… http://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/gpeyre/numerical-tours/blob/master/python/meshdeform_1_parameterization.ipynb…
------
Oldies but goldies: D.G Krige, A statistical approach to some mine valuations and allied problems at the Witwatersrand, 1951. Kriging (aka Wiener interpolation) accounts for uncertainty in kernel interpolation using a Gaussian processes. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kriging
------
The gradient field defines the steepest descent direction. The gradient flow dynamic defines a segmentation of the space into attraction bassins of the local minimizers. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gradient https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gradient_descent…
------
Oldies but goldies: Jont B. Allen, Short Time Spectral Analysis, Synthesis, and Modification by Discrete Fourier Transform, 1977. Popularized the used of the spectrogram as the baseline tool for audio processing. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spectrogram… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Short-time_Fourier_transform…
------
Edge collapse is a fundamental mesh processing primitive, at the heart of many mesh simplification methods. Influential papers by Hoppe, Garland and Heckbert.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Progressive_meshes… https://ri.cmu.edu/pub_files/pub2/garland_michael_1997_1/garland_michael_1997_1.pdf…
------
Oldies but goldies: JA. Criminisi ; P. Perez ; K. Toyama, Region filling and object removal by exemplar-based image inpainting, 2004. Introduces the idea of doing inpainting by pixel recopy. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inpainting

Oldies but goldies: Teuvo  Kohonen, Self-Organized Formation of Topologically Correct Feature Maps, 1982. Self-organizing maps of Kohonen defines a map between a 2D space to the data, by minimizing a quantization error and a regularity penalty. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-organizing_map…
------

Here phi'_inf is the limit of phi(x)/x as x grows. So if phi grows faster than linear functions (eg x*log(x)) then phi'_inf=+inf, the divergence is +inf is alpha does not have a density with respect to beta (in the discrete case, if beta is 0 then alpha must also be 0).

Oldies but goldies: Herbert Federer, Curvature measures, 1959. The co-area formula expresses the Total Variation semi-norm as the total perimeters of levelsets. Enables the computation of TV for non-smooth functions. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coarea_formula…
------
Moreau-Yosida regularization smoothes a function. It is the inf-convolution with a quadratic function. Its gradient is Id - the proximal operator.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convex_conjugate#Infimal_convolution…
------
It is also at the heart of optimal transport, often under the name of "c-transform" (here c(x,y)=|x-y|^2 is the transportation cost, and the inf-convolution exchanges two optimal dual potentials).
------
It also appears in the Hopf-Lax formula to solve Hamilton Jacobi equations (and in dynamic programming).
------
Oldies but goldies: Paul Chew, Guaranteed-quality mesh generation for curved surfaces, 1993. With Ruppert’s method, the first algorithm for provably good quality meshing of constrained domains. Based on the crucial idea of Delaunay refinement. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chew%27s_second_algorithm…
------
Sparse cholesky factorization are obtained by applying the algorithm after a careful reordering of the rows/columns. The minimum degree heuristic is surprisingly efficient.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minimum_degree_algorithm…
------
Oldies but goldies: Narendra Karmarkar, A New Polynomial Time Algorithm for Linear Programming, 1984. First efficient interior point method solving linear programs in polynomial time.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karmarkar%27s_algorithm…
------
The bilateral filter is a non-linear edge-preserving filter which where weights operate on both space and range values. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bilateral_filter…

Oldies but goldies: Fritz John, Extremum problems with inequalities as subsidiary conditions, 1948. Proves uniqueness of a maximum enclosed ellipsoid for compact convex sets. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_ellipsoid…
------
Sharp singularities attract solutions of optimization problems (here a projection on a set).  https://sites.math.washington.edu/~rtr/papers/rtr153-NonsmoothOptimization.pdf…
------
Oldies but goldies: R.E. Kalman, A New Approach to Linear Filtering and Prediction Problems, 1960. Kalman filter defines recursively an estimator of the parameters of a Gaussian dynamical process.  The basic method to control navigation systems. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kalman_filter…
------
Saddle points come with lots of flavors. Quadratic saddle are non-degenerate and repulse gradient descent. Higher order saddle point can attract gradient descent in a lot of directions. http://offconvex.org/2016/03/22/saddlepoints/… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saddle_point…
------
To clarify: blue indicates the initialization of the gradient descent and red where it converges.
------
Oldies but goldies: Herbert Federer, Curvature measures, 1959. The co-area formula expresses the Total Variation semi-norm as the total perimeters of levelsets. Enables the computation of TV for non-smooth functions. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coarea_formula…
------
Moreau-Yosida regularization smoothes a function. It is the inf-convolution with a quadratic function. Its gradient is Id - the proximal operator.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convex_conjugate#Infimal_convolution…
------
It is also at the heart of optimal transport, often under the name of "c-transform" (here c(x,y)=|x-y|^2 is the transportation cost, and the inf-convolution exchanges two optimal dual potentials).
------
It also appears in the Hopf-Lax formula to solve Hamilton Jacobi equations (and in dynamic programming).
------
Oldies but goldies: Paul Chew, Guaranteed-quality mesh generation for curved surfaces, 1993. With Ruppert’s method, the first algorithm for provably good quality meshing of constrained domains. Based on the crucial idea of Delaunay refinement. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chew%27s_second_algorithm…
------
Sparse cholesky factorization are obtained by applying the algorithm after a careful reordering of the rows/columns. The minimum degree heuristic is surprisingly efficient.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minimum_degree_algorithm…
------
Oldies but goldies: Narendra Karmarkar, A New Polynomial Time Algorithm for Linear Programming, 1984. First efficient interior point method solving linear programs in polynomial time.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karmarkar%27s_algorithm…
------
The bilateral filter is a non-linear edge-preserving filter which where weights operate on both space and range values. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bilateral_filter…
------
Oldies but goldies: Samuel Burer, Renato Monteiro, A Nonlinear Programming Algorithm for Solving Semidefinite Programs via Low-rank Factorization, 2001. Propose to use non-convex methods to solve large scale convex problems, very influential idea. http://optimization-online.org/DB_FILE/2001/03/296.pdf…
------
Csiszar divergences compare the relative densities of two measures with 1. Does not require any reference measure. Handles arbitrary measures (discrete or continuous). Canonical way to compare measures having the same support (strong topology). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F-divergence…
------
Here phi'_inf is the limit of phi(x)/x as x grows. So if phi grows faster than linear functions (eg x*log(x)) then phi'_inf=+inf, the divergence is +inf is alpha does not have a density with respect to beta (in the discrete case, if beta is 0 then alpha must also be 0).
------
Oldies but goldies: Ron Kimmel, James Sethian, Computing geodesic paths on manifolds, 1998. Extends the fast marching method to work on triangulated surfaces. http://pnas.org/content/95/15/8431…
------
Gradient descent/ascent can be inefficient to find saddle point (Nash equilibrium) for min-max games, because of spiralling behaviour.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nash_equilibrium…
------
Oldies but goldies: S.  Wolfram, Statistical mechanics of cellular automata, 1983. Studies cellular automata and the chaotic behavior of certain rules such as rule 30. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cellular_automaton…

------
Low frequency Fourier approximation of a signal and an image generates ringing phenomena. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gibbs_phenomenon… http://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/gpeyre/numerical-tours/blob/master/python/introduction_4_fourier_wavelets.ipynb…

The stable marriage is solved by the Gale-Shapley algorithm. Shapley and Roth got the Nobel prize in economy for this. It is not symmetric (i<->j) but give an optimal match for each i. 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stable_marriage_problem…
------

------

Local averaging is consistent with the linear heat equation. Local median is consistent with the non-linear mean curvature motion. Linear blurs edges, non-linear preserves edges. Axiomatized by L. Alvarez, F. Guichard, P.-L. Lions, and J.-M. Morel. https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF00375127…
------
Oldies but goldies: James  Kajiya, The rendering equation, 1986. Describe conservation of light as an integral equation which is at the heart of global rendering technics such as radiosity. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rendering_equation…
------
The continuous wavelet transform was introduced by Grossman and Morlet. The decay of wavelet coefficients across scales characterizes the local regularity of a function. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuous_wavelet_transform…

The stable marriage is solved by the Gale-Shapley algorithm. Shapley and Roth got the Nobel prize in economy for this. It is not symmetric (i<->j) but give an optimal match for each i. 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stable_marriage_problem…
------
Oldies but goldies: Naum Z. Shor, Utilization of the operation of space dilatation in the minimization of convex functions, 1972. Introduces the ellipsoid method, which was later shown to provide polynomial time algorithm for linear programming. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ellipsoid_method…
------
Classification and Regression Trees (CART) defines structured recursive classification and regression functions. O(n*log(n)) time global optimization (despite the exponential number of models) is achieved by dynamic programming. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decision_tree_learning…
------
Oldies but goldies: MacAdam, Visual sensitivities to color differences in daylight, 1942. Showed that color perception can be modelled using an anisotropic metric. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MacAdam_ellipse…
------
Local averaging is consistent with the linear heat equation. Local median is consistent with the non-linear mean curvature motion. Linear blurs edges, non-linear preserves edges. Axiomatized by L. Alvarez, F. Guichard, P.-L. Lions, and J.-M. Morel. https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF00375127…
------
Oldies but goldies: James  Kajiya, The rendering equation, 1986. Describe conservation of light as an integral equation which is at the heart of global rendering technics such as radiosity. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rendering_equation…
------
The continuous wavelet transform was introduced by Grossman and Morlet. The decay of wavelet coefficients across scales characterizes the local regularity of a function. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuous_wavelet_transform…
------
Oldies but goldies: Derose, T.; Kass, M.; Truong, T., Subdivision surfaces in character animation, 1998. Showcases the use of subdivision surfaces for movie production.
------
The travelling salesman problem looks for the shortest Hamiltonian cycle in a graph.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Travelling_salesman_problem…
------
Oldies but goldies: E Noether, Ableitung der Elementarteilertheorie aus der Gruppentheorie, 1926. Introduces what are now called Betti numbers, which are topological invariants, which can be computed for simplicial homology using linear algebra. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Betti_number…
------
Low frequency Fourier approximation of a signal and an image generates ringing phenomena. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gibbs_phenomenon… http://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/gpeyre/numerical-tours/blob/master/python/introduction_4_fourier_wavelets.ipynb…
------
Oldies but goldies: Kostadin Dabov, Alessandro Foi, Vladimir Katkovnik, Karen Egiazarian, Image denoising by sparse 3D transform-domain collaborative filtering, 2007. BM3D was the state of the art image denoising method for a long time. http://cs.tut.fi/~foi/GCF-BM3D/
------
Julia sets are attraction bassins of iterated complex maps. The best known example is quadratic polynomials.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Julia_set
------
Oldies but goldies: David Cox, The regression analysis of binary sequences, 1958. Introduces logistic regression, one of the most widely used classification method. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logistic_regression…
------
Interpolating coefficients of polynomials generates interpolations between 2D point sets. Displayed using colors/level-sets for the angle/modulus of complex numbers. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Properties_of_polynomial_roots…  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vieta%27s_formulas…
------
Oldies but goldies: G. H. Golub, Christian Reinsch, Singular value decomposition and least squares solutions, 1970. The most popular algorithm to compute efficiently the SVD decomposition. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Singular_value_decomposition…
------
Approximation of a function on the sphere using an increasing number of spherical harmonics. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spherical_harmonics…

Mean curvature motion is the most fundamental curve evolution. Equivalent for curves of the heat equation. Independent of parameterisation and minimizes the length of the curve. It shrinks the curves toward an ellipse. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curve-shortening_flow… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mean_curvature_flow…
------
Oldies but goldies: David Broomhead, David Lowe, Multivariable Functional Interpolation and Adaptive Networks, 1988. Introduces RBF neural networks. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radial_basis_function_network…
------
Barzilai-Borwein method selects the step size for gradient descent using a cheap approximation of the Hessian. Performs usually (much) better than line search. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gradient_descent#Choosing_the_step_size_and_descent_direction…
------
Oldies but goldies: Isaac Newton, De analysi per aequationes numero terminorum infinitas, 1669. The standard second order method for root finding. Understanding its global convergence is hard. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newton%27s_method…
------
Zeros of random polynomials define point processes.  For iid coefficients, zeros cluster along the unit circle as the degree increases.  http://math.iisc.ernet.in/~manju/GAF_book.pdf…
------
Oldies but goldies: S.  Bernstein, Démonstration du théorème de Weierstrass fondée sur le calcul des probabilities, 1912. Constructive and quantitative proof of Weierstrass polynomial density in continuous function using Bernstein’s polynomials. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bernstein_polynomial…
------
Tarski–Seidenberg theorem: semi-algebraicity is stable by projection. The most fundamental result in semi-algebraic geometry.  Equivalent to the elimination of the existential quantifier. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tarski%E2%80%93Seidenberg_theorem…
------
Oldies but goldies: Martin Gardner, Mathematical Games - The fantastic combinations of John Conway's new solitaire game « life », 1970. The Game of Life is the most celebrated 2D cellular automaton. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conway%27s_Game_of_Life…
------
Thin plate (biharmonic) splines is an interpolation method with a closed form thanks to the theory of reproducing Hilbert spaces. Defines a Sobolev space of smooth functions. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thin_plate_spline… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radial_basis_function… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reproducing_kernel_Hilbert_space…
------
Oldies but goldies: Prim, R. C, Shortest connection networks And some generalizations, 1957. Computes the minimum spanning tree in n*log(n) operations. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kruskal%27s_algorithm…
------
Animated version ...
------
During elastic collision, particles of equal mass simply exchange their velocities. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elastic_collision… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inelastic_collision…
------
Oldies but goldies: Aleksandr Lyapunov, The general problem of the stability of motion, 1892. Lyapunov functions of an ODE are functions which decay along the flows of the ODE. The basic method to show convergence to a stationary point and its stability.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_function…
------
The soft-argmax is the gradient of the soft-max (log-sum-exp). Central to preform classification using logistic loss. Needs to be stabilized using the log-sum-exp trick. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Softmax_function… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LogSumExp

------
Oldies but goldies: Robert May, Simple mathematical models with very complicated dynamics, 1976. The logistic map is the simplest dynamical system which exhibits bifurcations toward chaotic behavior as a function of its parameter r. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logistic_map…
------
Fourier approximation of a cat. https://xkcd.com/26/
------
Oldies but goldies: Volker Strassen, Gaussian Elimination is not Optimal, 1969. Strassen algorithm reduces the complexity of matrix multiplication in term of number of multiplications. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strassen_algorithm…
------
Spherical interpolation (SLERP) of quaternions defines the geodesic over the rotations group. Storing rotations as quaternions is very convenient.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quaternions_and_spatial_rotation…
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slerp
------
Oldies but goldies: Henri Gouraud, Continuous shading of curved surfaces, 1971. Gouraud shading is the basic method to render illuminated surfaces by interpolation. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gouraud_shading…
------
Mean curvature motion is the most fundamental curve evolution. Equivalent for curves of the heat equation. Independent of parameterisation and minimizes the length of the curve. It shrinks the curves toward an ellipse. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curve-shortening_flow… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mean_curvature_flow…
------
Oldies but goldies: David Broomhead, David Lowe, Multivariable Functional Interpolation and Adaptive Networks, 1988. Introduces RBF neural networks. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radial_basis_function_network…
------
Dynamics of a system of rods (multiple pendulum) is an ODE evolution on an 2nd order algebraic variety. Defines highly complex patterns as soon as n>2.   https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Double_pendulum…
------
Jacob Bernoulli, Ars Conjectandi, 1713. Introduces many concepts central in probability, including the binomial distribution. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ars_Conjectandi…
------
Surface parameterization computes a diffeomorphism between a 3-D surface and a « simple » domain. Here parameterizing an elephant on a sphere and half of an elephant on a disk. http://sites.fas.harvard.edu/~cs277/handouts/param.pdf…

Oldies but goldies: John Hammersley, Percolation processes, 1957. Percolation on a square random lattice exhibit a phase transition when the probability of occupation is 1/2. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Percolation_theory…

In the static regime, the electric field generated by point sources is the superposition of radial electric monopoles. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electromagnetic_field… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magnetic_dipole…
------
The proof is the same as for SVD: applying PF to A*B and to B*A to define v and u, and then realize that B*u and A*v satisfy the same relation, so they are multiples of v and u by uniqueness.

Oldies but goldies: P. L. Lions and B. Mercier, Splitting Algorithms for the Sum of Two Nonlinear Operators, 1979. Douglas-Rachford algorithm (dual of ADMM) minimizes the sum of two convex functions. Typical convergence pattern is spiralling. https://regularize.wordpress.com/2017/02/24/the-origin-of-the-douglas-rachford-iteration/…

Large scale N-body simulations requires to evaluate sums involving long-range interaction kernels, 1/r^2 for gravitation/electric fields. Fast multipoles and Barnes–Hut methods approximate these sums in n*log(n) operations instead of n^2. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/N-body_simulation…
------
Oldies but goldies: Stuart Lloyd, Least squares quantization in PCM, 1982. Continuous counterpart of k-means. Optimizes the optimal quantization energy, which is an optimal transport distance to free Dirac masses. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lloyd%27s_algorithm… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vector_quantization…
------
Zonohedra are images of l^inf ball by linear map while symmetric polyhedra are images of the l1 ball. Zonoids are limits of zonohedra. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zonohedron
------
Oldies but goldies: Gaston Julia, Mémoire sur l'iteration des fonctions rationnelles, 1918. Julia sets are attraction bassins of iterated complex maps. The best known example is quadratic polynomials. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Julia_set http://sites.mathdoc.fr/JMPA/PDF/JMPA_1918_8_1_A2_0.pdf…
------
De Casteljau’s algorithm defines a subdivision’s algorithm to evaluate Bezier’s curves. It revolutionised computer aided geometric design. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De_Casteljau%27s_algorithm… https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/B%C3%A9zier_curve…

http://pnas.org/content/pnas/93/4/1591.full.pdf…
